div0.head: *c
div0.entryFree:
*c c, cei= (q.v.), to/, indecl., fifteenth (later fourteenth) letter of most of the Eastern Greek alphabets, including the Ionic (later general Gr.) alphabet ; not used in Western Greek alphabets or in the native Attic alphabet ; in form and serial position (IG14.2420) it corresponds to the Semitic
samech (a form of
s), but has acquired the new value
ks ; as numeral c' = 60, but c' = 60,000.

cai/nw, fut. ca^nw= Ar.Av.827 : aor. e)/chna E.Or.12 :—Pass., aor. e)ca/nqhn (v. infr.) : pf. e)/casmai (kat-) Hp.Ulc.24, (a)n-) Gal. ap. Orib. 51.57.3, e)/cammai Thphr.CP3.23.2, Gp.3.1.7, (kat-) D.S.17.71 :—
scratch, comb, esp. of wool,
card, ei)/ria/ te cai/nein Od.22.423 ; ste/mmata c., of Fate, E.l.c.: abs.,
dress wool, Trag.Adesp.9, Ar.Lys.536, Ec.89,92, Pl.Sph.226b, etc.: c. gen. partit., tw=n e)ri/wn c. Ar.Fr.717, Crates Theb.3 : metaph., c. eu)/noian ei)s kalaqi/skon Ar.Lys.579 ; c. ei)s pu=r, prov. of labour in vain, Pl.Lg.780c. of cloth,
full, dress it, c. to\n pe/plon Ar.Av.l.c. metaph.,
thresh, h(ni/k' a)\n canqh=| sta/xus dub. in A.Fr.304.7 (leg. h(ni/k' e)canqh=|);
fret, mangle, of waves, canqe\n u(po\ spila/di AP6.223 (Antip.), cf. 23 ; u(/dwr caino/menon
fretted into foam, A.R.4.1266 ; of bodies,
mangle, lacerate, caino/menos peri\ th=| gh=| D.H.3.30 ; esp. of flogging, c. to\ sw=ma ma/stici ibid. ; r(a/bdois e)/cainon ta\ sw/mata Plu.Publ.6, cf.Ach.Tat.6.20 (Pass.) : c. acc. cogn., c. kata\ tou= nw/tou polla\s (sc. plhga/s) D.19.197 ; melei+sti\ c. Philostr.Her.19.18 ; also cai/nousa pareia\s da/krusin AP7.464 (Antip.) ; of the throat, in Pass.,
to be irritated, sore, Antyll. ap. Orib.10.34.8 ; of the mind,
fret, worry, cai/nesqai th\n yuxh\n fronti/di J.AJ1.1.4.
ca/mma, atos, to/, = ca/sma, Hsch. s.v. pei=kos.

ca^na/w, fut. -h/sw Suid.:—
grow weary with carding wool : hence, generally,
work hard, grow weary, canh=sai S.Fr.498 ; neu/rwn cana/a| kexalasme/na desma/ Nic.Th.383.
ca/ndaros, o(, a fabulous sea-monster of the Atlantic, Hsch.

*candiko/s, o( (sc. mh/n), name of a month in the Macedonian calendar, PCair.Zen.3.43, al. (iii B. C.), IGRom.4.661.33 (Acmonia, i A.D.), etc. :—written *canqiko/s, D.S.18.56, LXX 2 Ma.11.30, Suid., etc. ; also *canqika/, ta/, festival held in this month, Hsch.

ca/nqh, h(,
a pale-coloured stone, Thphr.Lap.37.

*canqi/as, ou, o(,
Xanthias, typical name of a slave in Greek comedy (from his yellow wig), Ar.Ach.243,Av.656,V.1,Ra.1, cf. Aeschin. 2.157.
a throw of the dice, Hsch., cf. Eub.59.

canqi/zw, (canqo/s)
make yellow or
brown, by roasting or frying, Ar. Ach.1047, cj. in Philem.79.6 ; e)canqisme/nai
with hair dyed yellow, Ar. Lys.43 (v.l. for e)chnqisme/nai), cf. Com.Adesp.289 ; dub. in D.H.7.9 ; th\n tri/xa -o/menos Duris 10 J. intr.,
to be yellow, LXXLe.13.30 ; tri/xes-ousai Alciphr.Fr.5.4.
*canqiko/s, o(, v. *candiko/s.

ca/nq-ion, to/, a plant used for dyeing the hair yellow,
Xanthium Strumarium, broad-leaved burweed, Dsc.4.136, Gal.12.87. = curi/s, Ps.-Dsc.4.22.

ca/nq-i^sis, ews, h(,
dyeing yellow, Gal.12.446.

ca/nq-isma, atos, to/,
that which is dyed yellow, ko/mhs canqi/smata
dyed hair, E.Fr.322, cf. AP5.259 (Paul. Sil.).
canq-ismo/s, o(, = ca/nqisis, Archig. ap. Gal.12.445.

canqo/-gews, wn,
of yellow soil, Luc.Syr.D.8.

canqo-derkh/s, e/s,
with fiery eyes, of a dragon, B.8.12.

canqo-eidh/s, e/s,
yellow in appearance, Heph.Astr.1.1.

ca/nqo-qric, o(, h(, gen. trixos,
yellow-haired, Sol.22 (v.l. purro/-), Theoc.18.1 ; c. a)/nqos Aglaïas 13 ; of a horse,
chestnut, B. 5.37.

canqo-ka/rhnos [ka^], on,
with yellow head, of Dionysus, AP9.524.15.

canqo-ka/ru^on [ka^], to/,
clove, Aët.8.29.
canqo-ko/mhs, ou, o(, = canqo/qric, Hes.Fr.135.5, Pi.N.9.17, Theoc.17.103 (v.l. canqo/-komos, as also in Opp. C.2.165,3.24).

canqo/-leukos, on,
pale yellow, Gal.17(1).835.
canqo/-lofos, on, gloss on foiniko/lofos, EM797.39, Hsch. (canqou= lo/fou cod.), Suid.

canqo-mh/linos, on,
greenish-yellow, Zos.Alch.p.243B.

canqo/s, h/, o/n,
yellow, of various shades, freq. with a tinge of red,
brown, auburn, lampro\n e)ruqrw=| leukw=| te meignu/menon Pl.Ti.68b ; e)/sti de\ to\ c. e)n th=| i)/ridi xrw=ma metacu\ tou= te foinikou= kai\ prasi/nou xrw/matos Arist.Mete.375a11 ; canqo\n e)reu/qesqai AP12.97 (Antip.) : in Ep. mostly used of
fair, golden hair, c. ko/mh, xai/th, of Achilles, Il.1.197, 23.141 ; c. tri/xes, of Odysseus, Od.13.399,431 ; ka/rh c. *mene/laos (but usu. c. M. alone) 15.133 ; also of women, c. *)agamh/dh Il.11.740 ; *)aria/dnh Hes.Th.947 (but c. *dhmh/thr
golden corn, Il.5.500, etc.) ; so later, of Helen, Sapph.Supp.13.5 ; of Athena and the Graces, Pi.N.10.7, 5.54 ; of Harmonia, E.Med.834 (lyr.) (but in later Gr. of complexion, Cleom.2.1) ; of dyed hair, th\n gunai=ka th\n sw/fron' ou) dei= ta\s tri/xas c. poiei=n Men.610 ; also of horses,
bay, i(/ppwn c. ka/rhna Il.9.407, cf. 11.680 ; c. pw=loi Alc.Supp.8.14, S.El.705 ; bow=n canqa\s a)ge/las Pi. P.4.149 ; c. le/wn Id.Fr.237 ; pw/lou di/khn, h(/ tis . . qe/ros qerisqh=| canqo\n au)xe/nwn a)/po S.Fr.659.4, etc. after Hom. of all kinds of objects, a)/rtoi c. Xenoph.1.9 ; canqw=n sponda\s melitw=n v.l. in Emp. 128.7 ; i)/wn c. a)kti=nes Pi.O.6.55 ; c. nefe/la, of gold, ib.7.49 ; me/li Simon.47 ; flo/c B.Fr.3.4 ; a)kti=nes puro/s Sopat.13 ; e)lai/a A.Pers.617 ; of wine, c. *)afrodisi/a la/tac S.Fr.277 (lyr.) ; of a roast pigeon, Ar. Ach.1106 ; canqai=sin au)/rais a)ga/lletai exults in its
yellow fragrance, of a fried fish, Antiph.217.22 : in Medic., freq. of bile, Hp.VM19, etc. : Comp. -o/teros Pl.R.617a : Sup. -o/tatos, bo/struxoi Pherecr. 189. *ca/nqos, parox., as pr. n., a stream of the Troad, so called by gods, by men Scamander, Il.20.74, etc. a horse of Achilles,
Bayard, the other being *bali/os,
Piebald, 16.149. name of a man, D.H.1.28, etc. fem., a city of Lycia, Hdt.1.176, etc.

canqo/ths, htos, h(,
yellowness, esp. of hair, Str.7.1.2.

canqo-tri^xe/w,
have yellow hair, Str.6.1.13.

canqo-fa^h/s, e/s,
goldengleaming, Jo.Gaz.Ecphr.1.58.

canqo-fu^h/s, e/s,
yellow by nature, e(/likes AP12.10 (Strat.) ; *dhw/, i(/ppos, Nonn.D.6.113,37.122.

canqo-xi/twn [i^], wnos, o(, h(,
with yellow coat, r(oih/ AP6.102（Phil.).
canqo/-xloos, gloss on foiniko/xloos, Hsch. (-xlois cod.).

canqo-xoliko/s, h/, o/n,
containing or
consisting of yellow bile, ai(=ma Gal.19.648（Comp.) ; xumo/s Alex.Trall.1.16.

canqo/-xolos, on,
suffering from jaundice, Ruf.Fr.80, Aët.3.66, dub. in Sch.Il.1.197.

canqo/-xroos, on, (xro/a, xrw/s)
with yellow skin, de/mas Mosch.2.84 : heterocl. acc. canqo/xroa Nonn.D.11.180.

canqo/-xrws, wtos, o(, h(, = foreg.,
brown, of fried fish, Nausicr.2.7.

canq-o/w,
dye yellow, Ps.-Democr.Alch.p.52 B. :—Pass.,
become yellow, Dsc.1.68.

canq-u/nomai, Pass.,
become brown, Thphr.HP3.15.6.

canq-wpo/s, o/n, (w)/y)
golden-looking, xroih/ Opp.C.2.382; xrw/s Nonn.D.18.113.
ca/nq-wsis, ews, h(, = ca/nqisis, Ps.-Democr.Alch. p.54B.

ca/n-ion, to/,
card for combing wool, Poll.5.96, AB284, Hsch. = e)pi/chnon, Poll.6.90,10.101.

ca/n-sis, ews, h(,
wool-carding, Gloss.

ca/n-ths, ou, o(,
wool-carder, Pl.Plt.281a.

can-tiko/s, h/, o/n,
of or for wool-carding : h( -kh/ (sc. te/xnh),
wool-carding, ib.281a, al. ; to\ -ko/n ib.282b.

ca/n-tria, h(, fem. of ca/nths, =
putatrix, Gloss. : *ca/ntriai, name of a play by Aeschylus.

ca/sma, atos, to/,
carded wool, S.Fr.1073.
catra/phs, v. satra/phs.

cei=, to/, indecl., name of the letter c, Calliasap.Ath.10.453d, BCH 29.483 (Delos), Phld.P0.2.3 : later ci= Luc.Jud.Voc.9, Sch.D.T.p.489 H., etc. ; cu= (by assimilation to nu=), f.l. in Luc. l. c. and AP9.385.14 (Steph. Gramm.).
ceina^pa/ths, cei/nh, cei/nhqen, Ion. for cen-.

ceinh/i+on, to/, (cei=nos) only found in Ion. and Ep. form,
host's gift to a guest, in full dw=ra ceinh/i+a Od.24.273 ; a)nti\ podo\s ceinh/i+on, ironically, 22.290 ; also,
provision made for a guest, ceinh/i+a polla\ fago/nte 4.33 : more generally,
gifts of (guest-) friendship, a)llh/loisi po/ron ceinh/i+a kala/ Il.6.218.
ceini/zw, ceini/h, ceiniko/s, cei/nion, cei/nios, v. cen-.

ceino-ba/kxh, h(,
mad for love of the stranger, of Medea, Lyc. 175.
ceino-doke/w, ceino-do/kos, ceino-ktone/w, Ion. for cen-.
cei=nos, ceinosu/nh, ceino/w, v. cen-.
cei/rhs, ceiri/s, v. curi/s.

ce/legnon, to/, dub. sens. (perh.
writing-tablet), POxy.1297.18 (iv A. D.).

cena_g-e/ths, ou, o(,
one who takes charge of guests, *delfoi\ c. the
hospitable Delphians, Pi.N.7.43.

cena_g-e/w,
to be a leader of mercenaries, c. cenikou= X.HG4.3.15, cf. 4.3.17, D.23.139, Arr.Fr.99J.
guide strangers, show them the sights, a)/rista/ soi e)cena/ghtai your
work as a guide has been done excellently, Pl.Phdr.230c ; cenagou/menos
one seeing the sights, ibid. ; cena/ghso/n me ne/hlun o)/nta Luc.DMort.18.1, cf. Cont.I : metaph., generally,
guide, direct, Alciphr.1.26 ; c. tina\ pro\s ta\s *mou/sas Them.Or.9.123b, cf. Ph.2.330 :—Pass., u(po\ sofi/as c. Id.1.630. Med.,
receive hospitality, Procop.Goth.3.9 :—so in Pass., ib.4.22.

cena_/g-hsis, ews, h(, = Lat.
conscriptio, ui(w=n App.BC 5.74.

cena_g-i/a, h(,
office of cenago/s,
command of a body of mercenaries, Id.Hisp.44. = su/ntagma, Ael.Tact.9.4, Arr.Tact.10.3.
force of two yilagi/ai, Ael.Tact.16.3, Arr.Tact.14.4, prob. in Ascl. Tact.6.3.
guiding of strangers, Hld.7.13.

cena_g-o/s, o(, (ce/nos, a)/gw)
commander of mercenary troops, Th.2.75 (ubi v. Sch.), X.HG 4.2.19, PCair.Zen.374.5 (iii B. C.), SIG556D3 (Delph., iii B. C.), etc. (Dor. form (Cretan acc. to AB284) adopted in Att. like other military terms.)
commander of a cenagi/a 1.2, Ael.Tact.9.4, Arr.Tact.10.3.
cicerone, guide, Plu.2.567a, Hld.7.14 (v.l. -agwgo/s).
cen-a^gwge/w, = cenage/w, Hsch.
cen-a^gwgo/s, o/n, later form for cenago/s II, f.l. in Th.2.75 and Plu.Ages.36.

cen-a^pa/ths [pa^], ou, o(, poet. cein-, (a)pata/w)
one who cheats strangers, Pi.O.10(11).34.
one who betrays his host, Ibyc.Oxy.1790i10, E.Med.1392 (anap.).
a treacherous breeze within a harbour, while another is blowing at sea, AB109.

cen-a^pa^ti/a, h(,
cheating of guests, Pl. Ep.350c.

cen-arkh/s, e/s, (a)rke/w)
aiding strangers, Pi.N.4.12.

ce/n-h, h(, fem. of ce/nos : (sc. gunh/)
foreign woman, A.Ag.950, etc. (sc. gh=)
foreign country, e)n ce/na| S.Ph.135(lyr.); e)pi\ ce/nhs X.Lac.14.4 ; e)pi\ c. katabiou=n Phld.Rh.2.146S., cf. Plu.2.576c, etc.
cen-hdo/xos, on, = cenodo/kos, Men.Mon. 402.

ce/n-hqen, Ion. cei/n-, Adv.
from abroad, Opp.H.4.153.

cen-h/koustos, on,
foreign, of words, Hdn.Epim.3.

cen-hla^si/a, h(, at Sparta,
expulsion of foreigners, X.Lac.14.4 : mostly in pl., Th.1.144, 2.39, Pl. Prt.342c, Lg.950b, Arist.Pol.1272b17.

cen-hla^te/w,
banish foreigners, in Pass., Ar.Av.1013, Plb.9.29.4, D.S.40.3.

cen-i/a, h(, Ep. ceni/h Od.24.286 ; Ion. ceini/h (v.l. ceinhi/+h) Hdt. (v. infr.) : (ce/nos) :—
hospitality shown to a guest, entertainment, dw/roisin a)meiya/menos . . kai\ ceni/h| a)gaqh=| Od.24.286 ; mei/cesqai ceni/h| h)d' a)glaa\ dw=ra didw/sein ib.314 ; kata\ ceini/hn
hospitii causa, Hdt.2.182 ; e)pi\ ceni/an e)lqei=n to come
as a guest, Pi.N.10.49 ; but, e)pi\ ceni/an kalei=n, parakalei=n, also e)pi\ ceni/a| kalei=sqai, kalei=n, prob. only as f.l. for e)pi\ ce/nia, v. ce/nios 1.2 : in pl., Id.O.4.17 ; ceni/ai kai\ filo/thtes And.1.145 ; e(toi/maze/ moi c. Ep.Philem.22.
friendly relation between two states, or between a person and a foreign state, ceini/hn tini\ sunti/qesqai, Lat.
hospitium facere cum aliquo, Hdt.1.27,3.39 ; c. toi=si *)akanqi/oisi proei=pe Id.7.116 ; e)poih/santo o(/rkia ceini/hs pe/ri kai\ summaxi/hs Id.1.69 ; dialu/sasqai th\n c. Id.4.154 ; ta\s palaia\s c. a)nanew/sasqai Isoc.4.43 ; kata\ th\n c. because of their
friendly relations, Th.8.6 ; dia\ th\n c. Plu.2.816a ; pro\s c. ta=s sa=s by thy
friendship with us, S.OC515 (lyr.) ; c. tino/s
with him, D.18.51 ; fili/an kai\ c. ib.284.
status of an alien, opp. that of a citizen, grafh\ ceni/as indictment
of an alien for usurping civic rights, Id.Ep.3.29 ; ceni/as feu/gein (sc. grafh/n) to be so indicted, Ar.V.718 ; a)gwni/sasqai Lys.13.60 ; a(li/skesqai D. 24.131 ; ceni/as gra/yasqai/ tina Id.40.41.
guest-chamber, PSI 1.50.16 (iv/v A. D.) ; perh.
lodging, Act.Ap.28.23.
cen-ia_go/s, o(, = cenago/s, Sammelb.6801.32 (s.v.l., iii B. C.).

cen-i/dion, to/,
guesthouse, PTeb.335.17 (iii A. D.).

cen-i/zw, Ion. and Ep. ceini/zw, fut. -iw=, later -i/sw Gp.12.13.12 : Ep.aor.e)cei/nissa, cei/nissa, -isa (v. infr.) : (ce/nos) :—
receive or
entertain as a guest, cei/nous Od.3.355 ; to\n me\n e)gw\ . . e)u\+ e)cei/nissa 19.194 ; e)nnh=mar cei/nisse Il.6.174 ; cei/nis' e)ni\ mega/roisin ib.217 ; c. tina\ e)n do/mois E.Alc.1013, etc.; c. [tina\] si/toisi S.Fr.666 ; c. tina\ polloi=s a)gaqoi=s
to present with hospitable gifts, X.Cyr.5.3.2 ; u(ma=s e)n po/lei ceni/swmen w(=n . . ei)/xomen
with or
on what we had, Ar.Lys.1184 : metaph., o(\n . . *)/arhs ou)k e)ce/nisen, i.e. who fell not in battle, S.El.96 (anap.) : —Pass.,
to be entertained as a guest, Ar.Ach.73 ; cenisqei\s mh\ a)nticeni/sai Phld.Vit.p.30 J.; u(po/ tinos Hdt.1.30, X.HG3.1.24, etc.; para/ tini D.S.14.30, Act.Ap.10.6, 21.16 ; pro/s tina Philem.109 : metaph., laxa/noisin, w(/sper xh=nes, e)cenisme/noi Theopomp.Com.13.
surprise, astonish by some strange sight, ceni/zousan kai\ kataplhktikh\n pro/soyin Plb.3.114.4 ; c. th\n a)koh/n, of strange words, Hld.6.14 ; c. kai\ tara/ttein Gp.2.48.2 ; c. [th\n tw=n pollw=n sunh/qeian]
do violence to the ordinary use of language, Simp.in Cael.679.28 :—Pass.,
to be astonished, S.Ichn.137 ; tini Plb.1.23.5, 3.68.9, 1 Ep.Pet.4.12 ; dia\ to\ para/docon Plb.1.49.7 ; e)pi/ tini Id.2.27.4, D.S.31.2 ; kata/ ti Plb.1.33.1 ; mh\ suntrexo/ntwn u(mw=n 1 Ep.Pet.4.4 ; ei) . . M.Ant.8.15, cf. Vett.Val.302.17 ; pw=s . . PStrassb. 35.6 (v A. D.) ;
to be puzzled, unable to comprehend, Ael.Tact.1.6 ; of fresh leeches,
to be unaccustomed to the skin, Antyll. ap. Orib.7.21.1.
make strange, of plants and animals, i.e.
stunt their growth and distort them, Gp.9.5.3 (Pass.); tw=| plh/qei cenizome/nh h( fu/sis being
altered in character, Alex.Aphr.Pr.1.80, cf.Hippiatr.15. intr.,
to be a stranger, speak with a foreign accent, D.57.18 ; to\ ceni/zon th=s le/cews D.S.12.53, cf. Luc.Hist.Conscr.45.
to be strange or
unusual, of diseases, Gal.17(1).162 ; c. tw=| sxh/mati Luc.Anach.16 ; tw=| tri/bwni Id.Merc.Cond.24 ; qa/natos . . th=| to/lmh| ceni/zwn Id.Hist. Conscr.25.

ceniko/koufon, to/,
foreign cask, POxy.2153.5 (iii A. D., pl.).

cen-iko/s, h/, o/n, also o/s, o/n E.Ion722 (lyr.) ; Ion. ceiniko/s Hdt.1.77 :—
of or
for a stranger, of foreign kind, opp. a)stiko/s, A.Supp.618 ; c. i(kth=res E.Cyc.370 (lyr.) ; cenika/
taxes paid by aliens at Athens, c. telei=n D.57.34 ; su/ssitoi c., opp. politikoi/, Arist.Pol.1314a10 ; -wte/ras . . genome/nhs th=s bohqei/as
more connected with, or
dependent upon, foreigners, ib.1257a31 ; to\ c.
the class of aliens, ib.1278a7 ; also to\ c. (sc. dikasth/rion) the court
in which aliens sued or
were sued, ib.1300b24, cf. SIG306.24 (Tegea, iv B. C.), PHal.1.164 (iii B. C.) ; c. xalko/s
foreign money, PStrassb.103.8 (iii B. C.) ; c. a)rgu/rion IG12.313.57, 22.1436.56 ; c. no/misma Pl.Lg.742b ; c. e)mpo/rion PTeb.5.33 (ii B. C.) ; ta\ c.
alien property, IG9(1).333.3 (Oeanthea, v B. C.) ; c. boskh/mata, ta\ c. tw=n sperma/twn, Thphr.HP9.20.3, 8.8.1, cf. Pl.R.497b.
concerning the status of an alien, di/ka (cf. ceni/a 1.3) SIG526.25 (Crete, iii B. C.). in Thessaly, c. lu/trwsis manumission
which confers non-citizen status, IG9(2).28 : freq. cenikh=| alone, a)peleuqerou=sqai c. ib.14, al. of
foreign troops, etc., nh=es c. ships
furnished by the allies, Th.7.42 ; but usu. of hired troops, c. strato/s Hdt.1.77 ; to\ c., = oi( ce/noi,
a body of mercenaries, Ar.Pl.173, Th.[8.25], X.An.1.2.1, etc. ; ceniko\n tre/fein D.4.24. rarely = ce/nios,
hospitable, o( c. qeo/s
protector of guests, Pl.Lg.879e ; h( c. tra/peza Aeschin.3.224, cf. Dosiad.Hist.1 ; h( cenikh/ (sc. fili/a) friendship
between host and guest, Arist.EN1156a31. Adv. -kw=s
hospitably, Theopomp.Hist.225.
foreign, strange, no/maia, i(ra/, Hdt.1.135,172 ; to\ c., of laws,
their foreign origin or
character, Pl.Lg.702c ; c. lo/goi Ar.Ach.634 ; c. o)no/mata
non-Attic names, Pl.Cra.401c ; oi)=nos c. Alex.290, Diph.32.27 ; di/kaion tou\s ce/nous pi/nein ceniko/n Alex.230 ; glw=ssa, li/qos, PGiss.99.9(ii/iii A. D.), POxy.1449.46 (iii A. D.) ; a)gnwsto/tera kai\-w/tera Arist. Metaph.995a3 ; of style,
unfamiliar, i.e.
abounding in unusual words and phrases, c. le/cis Id.Rh.1406a15 ; to\ c. ib.1405a8, cf. Po.1458a22. Adv. -kw=s
in non-Attic fashion, Pl.Cra.407b.

ce/n-ios, a, on, Ion. cei/nios (as always in Hdt., and mostly in Hom., but ce/nios when the ult. is long, as in Od.14.158,389, 15.514, al.) :—
belonging to friendship and hospitality, hospitable, *zeu\s c. as
protector of the rights of hospitality, *zeu\s e)pitimh/twr i(keta/wn te cei/nwn te, cei/nios, o(\s cei/noisin a(/m' ai)doi/oisin o)phdei= (cf. ce/nos II) Od.9.271 ; *zhno\s . . e)dei/sate mh=nin ceini/ou Il.13.625, cf. A.Ag.61,362 (both anap.), al.; w)= *zeu= ce/nie Cratin.III ; also *)apo/llwn c. CIG2214e (Chios) ; c. tra/peza
the guests' table, Od.14.158, 17.155, Pi.I.2.39, etc.; c. koi/ta his
guest's adultery, Id.P.3.32 ; c. tini/
bound to one
by ties of hospitality, Hdt.5.63 codd. cei/nia, Att. ce/nia (cf. ceinh/i+on), ta/,
friendly gifts, given to the guest by his host, esp. meat and drink, cei/nia/ t' eu)= pare/qhken, a(/ te cei/nois qe/mis e)sti/n Il.11.779, cf.18.387, Od.5.91, etc.; ei)/ moi c. doi/h 9.229, cf. 19.185 (less freq. in sg., i(/na toi dw= cei/nion 9.356, cf. 20.296, Pi.P.4.35, SIG662.32 (Delos, ii B. C.)); ce/nia . . pare/sxe dai=ta
as a friendly gift, A.Ag.1590 ; bou=n ce/nia e)/pemyan X.HG7.2.3, cf. PCair.Zen.75.6 (iii B. C.) ; c. dou=nai E.Cyc.301 ; c. lh/yh| ib.342 ; de/casqai Lys.18.12 ; e)pi\ cei/nia kale/ein to invite one
to meat, Hdt. 2.107, 5.18, cf. IG12.19.14,108, X.HG6.4.20, Vect.3.4, D.7.20, etc. (e)pi\ ceni/an and e)pi\ ceni/a| freq. as f.l., X.Vect.l.c., D.l.c., D.S.8.25, 13.83, D.H.1.40, Philostr.VA3.33, etc.) ; e)pi\ cei/nia paralabei=n tina Hdt.4.154 ; c. proqei=nai, proqe/sqai, Id.7.29,135 ; e)paggei/lasqai katagwgh\n kai\ c. Id.6.35 ; ceni/ois de/xesqai/ tina X.An.5.5.24 : freq. of presents sent by peaceful inhabitants to an army, ib.5.5.2, 14,25, al.; of
provisions supplied to a king or official on a visit, Theopomp.Hist.22(d), PPetr.2p.25 (iii B. C.), PGrenf.2.14(b).9 (iii B. C.), etc.; also of
tribute, LXX 2 Ki.8.2, OGI132.11 (Egypt, ii B. C.); of
honoraria to artists, SIG689.10 (Delph., ii B. C.) : metaph., qa/natos ce/nia/ soi genh/setai E.Hel.480.
foreign, e)pi\ ceni/as (sc. gh=s) Antipho 2.2.9, Pl.Cra.429e, cf. Ath.Mitt.25.427 ; e)n ceni/h| Epigr.Gr. 1041.8. c. ko/smos, in Crete, magistrate who tried suits
with aliens, GDI4981.4,al.

cen-i/s, i/dos, h(,
road leading abroad, SIG636.24 (Delph., ii B. C.).

ce/n-i^sis, ews, h(, （ceni/zw）
entertainment of a guest or
stranger, c. poiei=sqai/ tinwn Th.6.46.

cen-ismo/s, o(, = foreg., Pl. Ly.205c, Luc.Salt.45, etc.; to\n c. poiei=n tw=| *(hraklei= SIG1106.61 (Cos, iv/iii B. C.); kale/sai tina\s e)pi\ cenismo/n BCH49.306 (Teos) : in
pl., Plu.Demetr.12, etc.
strangeness, novelty, Plb.15.17.1, D.S.3.33.
injurious effect of change, cenismoi\ u(da/twn Dsc.2.152 : but, generally,
change, tw=n cenismou= kai\ metapoih/sews xrh|zo/ntwn Antyll. ap. Orib.7.7.7; me/gas o( c. tou= sw/matos Gal.17(2).28 ; cenismo\n e)mpoiei=n Sor.1.116 ; c. stoma/xou Ruf. ap. Orib.7.26.152.
cen-isth/s, ou=, o(, = ce/nos I, Sch.Pi.P.4.52.

ceni_t-ei/a, h(,
living abroad, LXX Wi.18.3, Aristeas 249, Ptol.Tetr. III, Vett. Val.63.29 (pl.), Luc.Patr.Enc.8.
life of a mercenary in foreign service, Democr.246, PSI1.76.8 (vi A.D.).

ceni_t-euth/s, ou=, o(,
one who lives abroad, Rhetor. in Cat.Cod.Astr.8(4).148,166 (pl.).

ceni_t-eu/w,
live abroad, Timae.139, Nic.Dam. 1032 J., Str.14.5.13, Luc.Patr.Enc.8 ; c. pro/s tinas Aristeas 257 ;
live in exile, J.AJ16.11.8. Med.,
to be a mercenary in foreign service, Isoc.5.122, Ep.2.19 ; e)gw\ ceniteuo/menos e)strateuo/mhn Antiph.96.

ceno-da^i/+kths, ou, Dor. ceno/-ta_s, o(,
one who murders guests or
strangers, Pi.Parth.Fr.13.30 ; ceino- prob. cj. in E.HF391 (lyr.).

ceno-dai/ths, ou, Dor. ceno/-ta_s, o(, (dai/s)
one that devours guests or
strangers, of the Cyclops, Id.Cyc.658 (lyr.).

ceno-di/kai [i^], oi(,
judges who tried suits concerning aliens, at Athens, prob. in IG12.343.89, 342.38 ; at Oeanthea, ib.9(1).333.10 ; at Troezen, ib.22.46
a A 27 ; in Phocis, ib.9(1).32(ii B.C.): sg. only late, =
praetor peregrinus, Lyd.Mag.1.38 (-do/khs codd.).

ceno-doke/w, Ion. ceino-,
entertain guests or
strangers. Hdt.6.127, E.Alc.552, AP10.16 (Theaet.), etc. :—later ceno-doxe/w, 1 Ep.Ti.5.10, Max. Tyr.32.9, Cod.Just.1.3.45.1b.
testify, Pi.Fr.311 :— Med., Hsch.

ceno-do/kos, Ion. and Ep.ceinodo/kos, o(,
one who receives strangers, host, i(/n' o(mw=s terpw/meqa pa/ntes ceinodo/koi kai\ cei=nos Od. 8.543 ; cei=nos mimnh/sketai h)/mata pa/nta a)ndro\s ceinodo/kou 15.55, cf. Il.3.354, Od.8.210, Theoc.16.27, Jul.Or.2.96a, AP 10.15 (Paul. Sil.):—later ceno-do/xos, Ph.2.17, al.;
head of a cenodoxei=on, Just.Nov.7.1, al.
witness, Simon.84.7, cf. Hsch.—The forms cenodo/xos, -doxe/w, -doxi/a are condemned by Moer.p.271 P., Thom.Mag.p.251 R. ; cf. cenhdo/kos.

ceno-doxei=on, to/,
place for strangers to lodge in, inn, Jul.Ep.84a, Cod.Just.1.2.15.1, Just.Nov.120.1 Intr., PSI4.284.2, Suid., etc.
ceno-doxe/w, v. cenodoke/w.

ceno-doxi/a, h(,
entertainment of a stranger, X.Oec.9.10 (pl.), Thphr.Char.23.9 (pl.).
ceno-do/xos, v. cenodo/kos.
ceno-dw/ths, ou, o(, dub. sens., epith. of Dionysus, AP9.524.15.

ceno/-eis, essa, en,
full of strangers, E.IT1281 (lyr.).

ceno-qa/na^tos [qa^], on,
dying abroad, Critodem. in Cat.Cod.Astr.8(4).201.

ceno-qu^te/w,
sacrifice strangers, Str.7.3.6.

ceno-ka_dh/s, e/s,
caring for strangers, Pi.Pae. Oxy.841 Fr.131.

ceno-klei/deion, to/,
fund derived from Xenoclides, Inscr. Délos320 B78 (iii B. C.).

ceno-kra^te/omai, Pass.,
to be in the power of mercenary troops, Aen. Tact.12.4.
ceno-kri/tai [i^], oi(, = cenodi/kai, IGRom.3.681 (Patara): sg., title of official at Sparta, BSA26.163 (ii A.D.).

ceno-ktone/w, Ion. ceino-,
slay guests or
strangers, Hdt.2.115, E.Hec.1247, D.S.4.18.

ceno-ktoni/a, h(,
murder of strangers, Id.1.88, D.H.1.41 (pl.).
murder of a guest, Plu. 2.319d ;
of a host, Id.Dio54.

ceno-kto/nos, on,
slaying guests or
strangers, E.IT53, Aeschin.3.224 ; c. i(/ppoi Scymn.669, cf. Plu.Mar. 8.

ceno-kusta^pa/th [pa^], h(,
intrigue with strange women, AP11.7 (Nicandr. or Nicarch.).

cenolog-e/w,
enlist foreign troops, esp.
mercenaries, Isoc.5.96, D.40.36, Plb.3.27.4, LXX 1 Ma.4.35 ; c. e)k ta=s *)asi/as ei)s i)/dion po/lemon SIG 581.82 (Crete, ii B. C.) ; c. plh=qos misqofo/rwn Plb.1.9.6 :—Med., OGI 270.12 (Crete, iii B. C.) :—Pass., Plb. 14.7.5, al., CIG2623 (Citium), J. AJ13.4.9. metaph., c. e)/leon para/ tinwn
raise a contribution of pity, D.S.34/5.2.39.

cenolog-i/a, h(,
recruitment of mercenaries, Arist. Oec.1353b11, Plb.15.25.16, D.S.18.61.

cenolo/g-ion, to/,
army of mercenaries, Plb.29.23.6, 31.17.1, SIG581.40 (Crete, ii B. C.), OGI437.67, 71 (Pergam., i B. C.).

ceno/log-os (parox.), on,
enlisting mercenaries, Plb.1.32.1,5.63.9, D.S.14.62, Plu.Dio23 ; title of a comedy by Menander.

ceno-ma^ne/w,
have a rage for foreign fashions, Plu.2.527f.

ceno-pa/qeia [pa^], h(,
strange feelings, malaise, Sor.I.III, al.

ceno-pa^qe/w,
have a strange feeling, Plu.Phil.12 ; dusanasxetei=n kai\ c. Id.2.607e ; a)dhmonei=n kai\ c. ib.601c, cf. Sor.1.81.

ceno-poiki^lo/pteros, on,
with strange, motley plumage, koloio/s Tz.H.2.842.

ceno-poli/ths [i_], ou, o(,
pertaining to an alien, no/mos Id.in Rh.3.670 W.

ceno-preph/s, e/s,
strange, out of the way, Hp Fract.1, D.H.Dem.34, Aret.SD2.13 (Comp.). Adv. -pw=s Steph. in Hp.2.288 D.

ceno-pro/swpos, on, only in Adv. -pws,
with reference to a person other than oneself, Sch.Aristid. p.430 D.

ce/nos, o(, Ep. and Ion. cei=nos (also freq. in Pi., N.7.61, al., used by Trag. metri gr. even in trim., mostly in voc., S.OC33, al., E.IT798 codd., El.247), Aeol. ce/nnos Hdn.Gr.2.302 ; scanned _^ and written cei=nos in Theoc.28.6, 30.17 : Aeol. Sup. cenno/tatos Sch. Tz. in An. Ox. 3.356.18 (sed v. fin.).
guest-friend, applied to persons and states bound by a treaty or tie of hospitality, Od.1.313, etc. ; cei=noi de\ . . eu)xo/meq' ei)=nai e)k pate/rwn filo/thtos 15.196 ; c. patrw/i+o/s e)ssi palaio/s Il.6.215 ; c. d' a)llh/lwn patrw/i+oi eu)xo/meq' ei)=nai Od.1.187 ; fhsi\ d' *)odussh=os cei=nos patrw/i+os ei)=nai 17.522 ; later freq. coupled with fi/los, *plou/tarxos o( tou/tou ce/nos kai\ fi/los D.21.110, cf. 18.46, X.An.2.1.5, Lys. 19.19 ; basile/ws patriko\s c. Pl.Men.78d. of parties giving or receiving hospitality, Od.8.145, etc. ; mostly of the
guest, opp. the host, ceinodo/koi kai\ cei=nos ib.543, etc. ; a( cei/na the
visitor, Theoc.2.154 ; of
guests at a club, opp. su/ndeipnoi, PTeb.118.4 (ii B. C.) : less freq. of the
host, Il.15.532, A.R.1.208, Ep.Rom.16.23, etc. : c. dat., cei=no/s tini Hdt.1.20,22, cf. Th.2.13, X.An.1.1.10, etc. ; also c. tino/s ib. 2.4.15.
stranger, esp.
wanderer, refugee (under the protection of *zeu\s ce/nios), sts. coupled with i(ke/ths, *zeu\s e)pitimh/twr i(keta/wn te cei/nwn te cei/nios Od.9.270, cf. 8.546; with ptwxo/s, pro\s ga\r *dio/s ei)sin a(/pantes cei=noi/ te ptwxoi/ te 6.208. generally,
stranger,
foreigner, opp. e)/ndhmos, Hes.Op.225; opp. a)sto/s, Pi.O.7.90, S.OC13, And.4.10, etc. ; poliata=n kai\ c. Pi.I.1.51, cf. A. Th.924 (lyr.), Pl.Grg. 473d, etc. ; opp. e)pixw/rios, Id.Men.94d: coupled with me/toikos, Th. 4.90, cf. IG12.39.53 ; with e)/phlus, Luc.Herm.24 ; opp. a member of the family, PMasp.169.10 (vi A. D.), etc. as a term of address to any
stranger, w)= ce/ne E.Ion247, Mosch.1.5, etc. ; w)= ce/nh Pl.Smp. 204c. = ba/rbaros, at Sparta, Hdt.9.11,55.
hireling, Od.14.102 ; esp.
mercenary soldier, IG12.949.89, X.An.1.1.10, D.18.152, etc. ; c. nauba/tai Th.1.121 : rarely simply,
ally, X.Lac. 12.3. as Adj. ce/nos, h, on (also os, on E.Supp.94), Ion. cei=nos, h, on,
foreign, not in Hom. (in the phrases cei=ne pa/ter Od.7.28, a)/nqrwpoi cei=noi Il.24.202, both words are Subst.) ; freq. in later writers, cei/na gai=a Pi.P.4.118 codd.; ce/nhs e)pi\ xqono/s S.OC1256 ; ga=s e)pi\ ce/nas ib. 1705 (lyr., cf. ce/nh); e)n ce/nh|si xersi/ by
foreign hands, Id.El.1141 ; c. do/moi, po/lis, etc., E.Ph.339 (lyr.), 369, etc. ; of
alien property, c. a)/rourai PMasp.295.22 (vi A.D.). c. gen. rei,
strange to a thing,
unacquainted with, ignorant of it, c. tou= lo/gou S.OT219, cf. AP4.3a.37 (Agath.); c. tw=n diaqhkw=n th=s e)paggeli/as Ep.Eph.2.12, cf. BGU405.12 (iv A. D.). Adv. ce/nws, e)/xw th=s e)nqa/de le/cews I am
a stranger to the mode of speech, Pl.Ap.17d ; e)/xein th=s diale/ktou Them. Or.21.253c.
strange, unusual, lo/goi A.Pr.688 (lyr.) ; timwri/ai Ti.Locr.104d ; poiei=n ce/nhn th\n dia/lekton Arist.Rh.1404b11, cf. 1415a7 ; ou)de\n c. e)n tw=| panti\ a)potelei=tai Epicur.Fr.266 ; toi=s ne/ois poiei=n ce/na ta\ fau=la Arist.Pol.1336b34 ; ce/na tai=s o)/yesi D.S.3.15 ; w(s ce/nou sumbai/nontos I Ep.Pet.4.12 ; didaxai\ poiki/lai kai\ c. Ep.Hebr.13.9 ; c. daimo/nia Act.Ap.17.18 : Sup., pra/cewn w(s -ota/twn Phld.Herc.1251.5 ; c. au)tw=| dokei= to\ pra=gma Luc.Cont.13, etc. Adv. ce/nws, lalei=n Phld.P0.5.12. tou= pneu/matos . . r(u/sis w(s -wta/th air as
fresh as possible, Hp.Nat.Hom.9. (From ce/nvos, cf. pro/cenvos IG9(1).867, *cenva/rhs ib.869, *cenvoklh=s, *ce/nvwn, ib.4.315,348 : hence it is improb. that the Aeol. form was ce/nnos.）

cenosso/os, Ion. cein-, on,
saving strangers, Nonn.D.3.178.

ceno/-sta^sis, ews, h(,
lodging for guests or
strangers, S.OC90 ; pando/kos c. Id.Fr.274.
ceno/-stomos, on, = ceno/fwnos, Phld.Po.2.41.

ceno-su/nh, Ep. cein-, h(,
hospitality, Od.21.35.
ceno-ta/fion [a^], to/, gloss on polua/ndrion, Suid.

ceno/-ti_mos, on,
honouring strangers, A.Eu.547 (lyr.).
ceno/-tropos, on, gloss on e(tero/tropos, Sch. Opp.H. 1.379.

ceno-trofe/w,
maintain mercenary troops, Th.7.48, Isoc.8.46, Aen. Tact.13.1, D.11.18, LXX 2 Ma.10.14, Plu.2.214d ; c. mega/las duna/meis D.S.1.67 :—Pass., Aen. Tact. 13.4.

ceno-trofi/a, h(,
maintenance of mercenaries, Hyp.Fr.256, Aen. Tact.13 tit.

ceno-fone/w,
murder one's host, E.IT1021.

ceno-foni/a, h(,
murder of strangers, Isoc.11.36 (v.l. -ktoni/a).

ceno-fo/nos, poet. ceino-, on,
murdering strangers, a)/ndres Pl.Ep.336d ; ma/xaira Nonn.D.9.41. c. timai/ honour paid
to inurderers of strangers, E.IT776.

ceno-fu^h/s, e/s,
strange of shape or
nature, Tz.H.8.579, 636.

ceno-fu/lac [u^], a^kos, o(, in pl.,
magistrates charged with the protection of foreigners, Rev.Et. Gr.42.35 (Chios).

*cenofw=n, w=ntos, o(, Xenophon : hence Adj. ceno-fw/nteios, a, on,
of or
by X., lo/goi D.Chr.18.18.

cenofwn-e/w,
speak or
sound strangely, use out-of-the-way words, Dexipp. in Cat.6.17, Sophon.
in de An.47.12 :—Pass.,
to be disconcerted by strange expressions, Olymp.Alch. p.86 B. ; so intr. in Act., Sch.Il. 23.403.

cenofwn-i/a, h(,
strange language, Poll.2.113, Greg.Cor. Trop. 27.

ceno/fwn-os, on,
speaking or
sounding strange, rejected by Poll.2.113.

cen-o/w, Ion. ceino/w, (ce/nos)
make one's friend and guest, entertain, in Med., cenou=mai A.Supp.927, cf. A.R.1.849 : fut. cenw/setai Lyc. 92. mostly in Pass., with fut. Med. cenw/somai S.Ph.303 : pf. e)ce/nwmai : aor. e)cenw/qhn (e)cenw/qhsan *)attikw=s: e)ceni/sqhsan *(ellhnikw=s Moer.p.167 P.):
enter into a treaty of hospitality with one, po/lies a)llh/lh|si e)ceinw/qhsan Hdt.6.21, cf. Pl.Lg.642e, X.Ages.8.5 ; basileu=sin e)cenwme/nos Lys.6.48 : abs., X.HG4.1.34.
take up one's
abode with one
as a guest, to be entertained, *qh/ba| cenwqei/s Pi.P.4.299, cf. A.Ch.702, S. l. c., etc. ; cenwqei\s toi=sd' e)n . . do/mois E.Alc.68 ; cenou=tai tw=| *cenofw=nti, [par'] *(ella/di, X.An.7.8.6,8 ; cenwqei\s u(po\ ta=s boula=s IG12(1).383 (Rhodes).
reside abroad, daro\n e)cenwme/nou S.Tr.65, cf. E.Ion 820 ;
go into banishment, Id.Hipp. 1085. later, in Act.,
deprive one
of a thing, [tina/] tinos Hld.6.7.
cen-u/drion, to/, = cenu/llion, Men.462.3.
cen-u/llion, to/, Dim. of ce/nos, Plu.2.229e, 24od.

cen-w/n, w=nos, o(,
guest-chamber, in pl., E.Alc.543, 547 ; cenw=nas oi)=ge Com.Adesp. 1211, cf. D.S.13.83, J.BJ5.4.4: sg., Pl.Ti.20c; = cenodoxei=on, OGI609.21 (Syria, iii A. D.), Just.Nov.59.3 ; cf. cenew/n.

ce/n-wsis, ews, h(, (ceno/w)
entertainment of a guest, E.HF965.
ceri/as, cj. for o)ceri/as (q. v.).

cero/n, to/,
terra firma, once in Hom., poti\ cero\n h)pei/roio Od.5.402 ; poti\ cero\n e)/lq' a)po\ pe/tras to the
mainland, AP6.304 (Phan.), cf. A.R.3.322 ; e)pi\ cero/n Nic.Th.704. (Cogn. with sxero/s rather than with chro/s.）

ce/s-is, ews, h(,
planing, Thphr.HP5.6.4.

ce/s-ma, atos, to/, (ce/w)
that which is smoothed or
carved: hence, = co/anon, AP9.328 (pl., Damostr.); v. l. for cu=sma in Dsc.2.134.
abrasion, in pl., Jul. Caes.309c. pl.,
shavings, filings, M. Ant.8.50, S.E.P.1.129.
ces-mo/s, o(, in pl., = ce/sma II, Hsch. s.v. spara/gmasi.
ce/sse, v. ce/w.
cestasi/a, h(, dub. sens. in Sammelb.1160.10.

ce/st-hs, ou, o(, formed from Lat.
sextarius, a Roman measure nearly = 1
pint, IG7.3498.54 (Oropus), J.AJ9.4.4, AP11.298, Gal.13.435,
Damocr. ap. eund.13.989,IG42(1).93(Epid., iii/iv A.D.), Phlp.in APr. 27.19.
pitcher, cup, Ev.Marc.7.4, POxy.921.23 (iii A.D.), Harp.Astr.in Cat.Cod.Astr.8(3).139.

cest-iai=os, a, on,
of a ce/sths, me/tron Gal.13.435, cf. Phlp. in Mete.24.24.

cesti/zw,
polish, PMasp.6 ii 25 (Pass., vi A.D.).
cesti/on, to/, = ce/sths I, Ostr.Bodl.iii 357, Orib.Fr.28, Aët.6.28 : written cesti/n Arch.Anz.38/39.154 (Antioch). = ce/sths 11, Aët.1.138.

cesto/s, h/, o/n, (ce/w)
hewn, shaved, planed, of timber or objects made of it, c. ou)do/s, tra/peza, e)la/tai, e)fo/lkaion, Od.18.33,17.93, 12.172,14.350 ; i(/ppos 4.272 ; o)i+sto/s Hes.Sc.133 ; a)/kontes B.17.49 ; lo/xos *)argei/wn, of the wooden horse, E.Tr.534 (lyr.) ;
carved, co/ana prob. in Orac. ap. Phleg.Fr.36.10J. of stone,
hewn, e)pi\ cestoi=si li/qois Il.18.504, cf. Od.3.406 ; li/qou cestou= kai\ zw/|wn e)ggeglumme/nwn Hdt.2.124 ; a(rpa/cantes a)/galm' *)ai/+da, c. pe/tron, e)/mbalon ste/rnw| *poludeu/keos Pi.N.10.67 ; of buildings,
built of hewn stone, c. ai)/qousai Il.6.243 ; c. a)guiai/ E.HF782 (lyr.); c. tu/mbos, ta/fos, Id.Alc.836, Hel. 986 ; toi=xos LXX Si.22.17, J.AJ15.11.5. of horn,
polished, Od. 19.566 ; of an elephant's ears,
smooth, Opp.C.2.520.

cestourgi/a, h(,
process of hewing, li/qwn D.S.1.63.

ce/w, impf. e)/ceon Od.23.199 : fut. ce/sw Paul.Aeg.3.22.12 : aor. e)/cesa Sophr.110 ; Ep. ce/ssa Od.5.245, ce/sa Simon.185 A: pf. e)/ceka Choerob. in Theod.2.80:—Pass., Hsch.s.v. sparasso/meqa: aor. inf. cesqh=nai Gp.10.65.6, (kat-) Plu.2.953b: pf. e)/cesmai Ar.Fr.728, (a)p-) Hp.Nat.Mul.109: plpf. e)/cesto Hld.5.14:
—shave or
plane timber, ce/ssed' e)pistame/nws kai\ e)pi\ sta/qmhn i)/qunen Od.5.245,cf.17.341,21.44; oi( ce/ontes Pl.Thg.124b.
carve wood,
shape by carving, le/xos e)/ceon, o)/fr' e)te/lessa Od.23.199 ; ti/s nin ce/se; *sko/pas Simon.l.c.:—Pass., Hld.l.c.
whittle, pare, in grafting, Gp.4.12.14.
scrape smooth, polish, tou\s o)/nuxas Philostr.VS2.5.2 ; to\ ble/faron ce/somen dia\ kish/rews Paul.Aeg.l.c. ; to\ o)stou=n Id.6.2 ; sth/mwn e)cesme/nos
smoothed thread, Ar.l.c.
roughen by scraping, protetraxumme/nhs <kai\ oi(=on> e)cesme/nhs th=s u(ste/ras Sor.1.36 ;
irritate, e)/ntera Aret. SD2.9. = cai/nw,
flog, tou\s e)n dikasthri/w| cesqe/ntas kai\ cu/lois tufqe/ntas Orib.Fr.90 ; tou\s e)n dikasthri/w| mastigwqe/ntas kai\ cesqe/ntas Aët.15.37.
chno/s, o(, = kormo/s (i.e. e)pi/chnon), Suid.

chrai/nw, fut. -a^nw= E.Cyc.575: aor. e)ch/ra)na Th.1.109, Hp.Epid.2.3.2, but e)ch/rhna Id.Hum.1, Mul.2.112, Aret.CD1.3 :—Pass., fut. chranqh/somai Gal.1.516, etc., but Med. chra^nou=mai in same sense, Hp.Aff.25, Arist.Mete.356b25 : aor. e)chra/nqhn Il.21.345, Hp.Epid.5.30, Pl.Phlb.31e : pf. e)ch/rasmai Hp.Vict.2.66, Loc.Hom.29, Antiph. 217.13 ; e)ch/rammai Thphr.CP5.14.6, Ev.Marc.3.1, POxy.1188.19 (i A.D.), Sch.Ar.Pl.1082 ; inf. a)p-echra/nqai Hp.Mul.1.17 ; part. e)chra_me/nos only late, Sch.Porph.Abst.2.6 : (chro/s) :
—parch, dry up, chranei= s' o( *ba/kxios E.l.c.; of the sun, X.Mem.4.3.8, etc.; to\ sw=ma pro\s a)e/ra c. Jul.Or.6.203b ;
make costive, th\n koili/hn Hp.Aph.3.17, cf. 2.20 (Pass.):—Pass.,
to be or
become dry, parched, e)chra/nqh pedi/on Il.l.c., cf. Pl.Ti.88d, etc. ;
to be withered, e)chra/nqh h( sukh= Ev.Matt. 21.19, cf. Demetr.Lac.Herc.1012.12, POxy.l.c.
drain dry, chra/nas th\n diw/ruxa Th.1.109. metaph., kakouxei= au(to\n kai\ c. Teles p.34 H. Pass., of a paralytic, Ev.Marc.9.18.

chr-a^loife/w, (a)lei/fw)
rub dry with oil, of wrestlers, LexSolonis ap.Plu.Sol.I (cf. Aeschin.1.138), S.Fr.494, Plu.2.152d, Philostr. Gym.58, D.C.77.11 ; opp. xutlou=sqai, Gal.11.532.

chr-a^loifi/a, h(,
rubbing dry with oil, Eust.764.13, Suid.

chr-ampe/li^nos, h, on,
of the colour of withered vine-leaves, bright red, scarlet, [vestes] xerampelinae Juv.6.519 ; di/plakes c. Lyd.Mag.1.17 ; xlamu/des c. Suid. s.v. a)trabatika/s.

ch/r-ansis, ews, h(,
drying up, Gal.6.226, 16.415, Heph. Astr.1.22(pl.).

chr-ante/on,
one must dry, Dsc.5.88, Gal.10.104, Gp. 3.8.

chr-antiko/s, h/, o/n,
causing to dry up, c.gen., pneu/monos Hp.Acut. 16,22 : abs., c. [xulo/s] Thphr.CP6.1.3 ; c. di/aita Diocl.Fr.141, cf. Arist.Pr.925a34 (Comp.) ; c. du/namis Dsc.1.13. Adv. -kw=s
by drying. Herod.Med. ap. Orib.5.28.23.

chr-a^si/a, Ion. -ih, h(,
desiccation, Hp. Morb.1.18, Antiph.231.7, Arist.Mete.384a11 ;
keeping dry, Thphr. HP7.2.2 ;
drying of hay, PTeb.441(i A.D.), etc.
dryness, tou= perie/xontos Str.2.3.7; tou= kaulou= Dsc.2.142, cf. LXX Jd.6.37 ; chrasi/an lamba/nein become
dry, Agatharch.34.
drought, Gp.1.8.13 (pl.).

ch/r-asis,
siccitas, Gloss.
chr-asmo/s, gloss on au)asmo/s, Erot.
chr-a/fion, to/, = chri/on, Leonid. ap. Aët.14.13, Orib.Fr.84, Paul.Aeg.3.3 (freq. written cur- in codd.).

chr-i/on, to/,
desiccative powder for putting on wounds, POxy.1142.7 (iii A.D.), Aët.6.65,al., Alex.Trall.1.15 ; kriqai\ chri/on e)pipasso/menai toi=s e(/lkesi Alex.Aphr.Pr.1.150.

ch=r-is,
ardeola, Gloss. (prob. kei=ris).

chro-ba^la^niste/on,
one must insert a desiccant suppository, Orib. Fr.60.

chro-ba^tiko/s, h/, o/n,
walking on dry ground, of land-animals, opp. e)/nudros, Pl.Plt.264d ; of birds, Arist.HA559a20.

chro/-bhc, bhxos, o(,
dry cough, Cass.Fel.34(pl.).

chro/-dermos, on,
dry-skinned, Aët.1.107.

chro-ka^kozhli/a, h(,
tasteless aridity, Demetr.Eloc. 239.

chro/-karpos, on,
bearing dry fruit, Thphr.CP2.8.1 (Comp.).
chro-karuo/fullon, v. culokaruo/fullon.

chro-ke/fa^los, on,
dry-headed, Alex.Aphr.Pr.1.2.

chro-kollou/rion, to/,
dry, i.e.
thick, eye-salve, Gal. 12.725, Alex.Trall.2.

chro/-kopton, to/,
mortar, Hsch.s.v. i)/<g>dh (Rhod.).

chro-logi/a, h(,
gathering of dry brushwood, Sammelb.5126.25(iii A.D.).

chro-lousi/a, h(,
taking a dry bath, i.e. in hot sand, Cass.Fel.76.

chro-loutre/w,
take a dry bath, i.e. roll in hot sand, Hsch. (chral- cod.).

chro/-mu^ron, to/,
dry perfume, i.e.
in cake or
powder, PFay.331 (ii A.D.), Aët.16.127(118). =
rosmarinum, Gloss.

chro-nomiko/s, h/, o/n,
feeding on dry land, f.l. in Ath.3.99b (misquoting Pl.Plt.264d).

chro-poie/w,
make dry, dry up, v.l. in Dsc.5.103 (Pass.).

chro-poio/s, o/n,
drying up, parching, di/ya (as gloss on polukagke/a) Eust.871.3 ; gloss on karfale/os, Sch.Nic.Th. 691.

chro-po/tamos,
torrens, Gloss.

chro-pu^ri/a, h(, Medic.,
application of dry heat, Aët.16.29, Sch.Nic.Al.586, Gloss.
chro-pu_ri/ta_s [i_] a)/rtos, o(, (puro/s) = au)to/puros, Ameriasap.Ath.3.114c.

chro/s, a/, o/n,
dry, opp. u(gro/s, of a dried-up river, Hdt.5.45 ; xeima/rrous chrou\s u(/datos Arr.An.4.3.2 ; h)h\r c. Hdt.2.26 ; c. a)/nemos Ar. Nu.404 ; chroi=s a)klau/tois o)/mmasin A.Th.696; o)mma/twn c. ko/rai E.Or. 389 ; me/tra c. te kai\ u(gra/
dry and liquid measures, Pl.Lg.746d ; u(/lh au)/h kai\ c. ib.761d ; c. ga/la, i.e.
ripe cheese, Eust.1001.51 (cf. peri/chros) ; so turo\s c., opp. turo\s xlwro/s, Antiph.133.7, cf. Philox.3.8; e)n chroi=sin e)ktre/fein on
solid food, i.e. cereals, E.Ba.277 ; karpo\s c., i.e. cereal, opp. k. cu/linos, produce of trees, i. e. fruit, wine, or oil, Pl. Criti.115b ; c. xo/rtos
hay, PPetr.3p.181 (iii B.C.) ; foi=nic c.
dried dates, PSI1.33.14 (ii A.D.); c. karpoi/, opp. oi)=nos, e)/laion, Arr.Epict.2.23.5 ; c. puri/ai applications of
dry heat, Hp.Acut.21, Archig. ap. Gal. 12.621 ; cf. chropuri/a. Adv. chrw=s
by the use of dry powder, Hp.Epid. 6.3.13 (s.v.l.). of bodily condition,
withered, lean, de/mas E.El. 239 ; chro\s u(pai\ dei/ous Theoc.24.61 ; c. koili/h
costive, Hp.Aph.2.20. of the voice, cf. chro/fwnos.
fasting: hence, generally,
austere, tro/poi Ar.V.1452 (lyr.); of persons, Antiph.16 ;
harsh, opp. h(du/s, E.Andr.784 (lyr.). metaph., of style, pragmatei/a a)terph\s kai\ c. Epicur.Fr.505 (p.358 U.); to\ c.
aridity, Demetr. Eloc.238 ; of critics, chroi\ *kallima/xou pro/kunes AP11.322 (Antiphan.). as Subst. h( chra/ (sc. gh=),
dry land, opp. u(gra/, X.Oec.19.7 (also Comp. chrote/ra gh= ib.6), cf. Ev.Matt.23.15, etc. ; to\ chro/n Hdt.2.68 ; nau=s e)pi\ tou= chrou= poiei=n to leave the ships
aground, Th.1.109 ; nau=s e)s to\ c. e)cwqei=n Id.8.105 ; to\ c. tou= potamou=
the part of its bed
left dry, X.Cyr. 7.5.18: for Theoc.1.51 v. a)kra/tistos. chra/, h(, in a bath-house,
room for dry heat, POxy.2145.12 (ii A.D.).

chro/-sarkos, on,
dry of flesh, Diocl.Fr.135.

chro-smu/rnh, h(,
dry myrrh, Alex.Trall.12 fin.
chro-th/ga^non, to/, Syrac. for th/ganon, Hegesand.38.

chro/ths, htos, h(,
dryness, Pl.R.335d, X.Oec.19.11 ; h( c. tw=n new=n the
dryness, i.e.
soundness, of their timbers, Th.7.12.
drought, Plu.2.687f(pl.).
drying or
becoming dry, to\ ta/xos th=s c. Arist. Mete.361b22. metaph., of character,
austerity, Phld.Acad. Ind.p.51 M. ; of style,
aridity, Longin.3.3.

chro-tri^be/w,
rub dry, Agathin. ap. Orib.10.7.19.

chro-tri^bi/a, h(,
dry rubbing, Arist.Pr.966b1 (pl.), Gal.6.417.

chro-trofiko/n, to/,
rearing of land-animals, Pl.Plt.264d, 264e.

chro-fa^ge/w,
eat dry food, AP11.205 (Lucill.), Dsc.Eup.2.65, Sor.1.49.

chrofqalmi/a, h(,
inflammation of the eyelids, blepharitis sicca, with redness and smarting, Dsc.Eup.1.46, PMed.Strassb.p.6K., Cels.6.6, Erot.s.v. knipo/ths, Gal.12.731, Aët.7.77.

chro/-floios, on,
with dry bark, Gp.9.16.2.

chro/-forton, to/,
weight of a cargo of fruit
after drying, OGI629.164 (Palmyra, ii A.D.).
chro/-frukton, to/, = chro/muron, Aët.16.126(117).

chro/-fwnos, on,
with a husky voice, Sch.D ll.13.41 ; to\ c., of the twang of a bowstring, Eust.1914.42.

chro-xeima/rrous, o(,
dry watercourse, Hero
*Geom.4.13.

chrw/dhs, es,
dryish, looking dry, EM557.27.
ci=, v. cei=.
ci/mbra, h(, Aeol. for r(oia/, Hsch.
ci^poma/kaira [ma^], barbarism in Ar.Th.1127, for cifoma/xaira.
ciri/s, = curi/s, Dsc.4.22 :—also ci/ris, v. curi/s.

entryFree.foreign: ta\ e)n tai=s r(uka/nais dre/pana h)\ sidh/ria,

div0.entryFree:
cifh/n, h=nos, o(,
sword-bearer, Suid.

ci^fh/rhs, es,
armed with a sword, sword in hand, E.Or.1272,1346, al.: also in later Prose, Phld.Rh.2.89 S.(dub.), Ap.Ty.Ep.36, Hdn. 7.5.3, Iamb.VP25.113, Malch.p.410 D.

ci^fh-fore/w,
wear a sword, Ph.1.282, Hdn.7.11.4.

ci^fh-fori/a, h(,
wearing of a sword, Suid.

ci^fh-fo/ros, on,
bearing a sword, sword in hand, E.Or.1504,al.; c. a)gw=nes A.Ch.584, E.HF812 (lyr.); bro/xoi ib.730; xei=res Antiph.217.19,cf. Callistr.Stat.13: as Subst.,
swordsman, Hdn.7.10.7. = cifi/as 11, Sch.Arat.1091.

ci^f-i/as, ou, o(, (ci/fos)
sword fish, Arist.HA505a18, Fr.325,Archestr. Fr.40; cf. skifi/as. a kind of
comet (from the shape), Plin.HN 2.89.

ci^f-i/dion, to/, Dim. of ci/fos,
dagger, Ar.Lys.53, Th.3.22,POxy. 936.9 (iii A.D.), etc. = sparga/nion, Ps.-Dsc.4.21.

ci^f-i/zw,
dance the sword-dance, Cratin.219.

ci^f-i/nda, Adv.
sword-game, Theognost.Can.164.

ci^/f-ion or ci^f-i/on, to/,
corn-flag, Gladiolus segetum, Thphr.HP6.8.1, Dsc.4.20.
ci^/f-ios (ci^f-io/s cod. Hsch.), o(, = cifi/as, Hsch. a fish like the i)ouli/s, Cyran.3<*>. a stone, ibid. a bird, = ki/rkos, ibid.
ci^/f-isma, atos, to/, = sq., Choerob. in An.Ox.2.242, cf. Hsch. (pl.).

ci^f-isth/r, h=ros, o(,
sword-belt, PCair. Zen35.2 (iii B.C.). Plu.Pomp.42, Hld.9.23.
ci^f-isth/s, ou=, o(, = foreg., Hsch.

ci^f-istu/s, u/os, h(, = maxairomaxi/a,
sword-play, Id.

ci^fo-dh/lhtos, on,
slain by the sword, c. qa/natos, a)gw=nes, death
by the sword, A.Ag.1528, Ch.729 (both anap.).

ci^fo-dre/pa^non, to/,
sickle-shaped sword, scimitar, Ph.Bel.99.51, POxy.1241 vi 22 ; = a(/rph, Hsch.

ci^fo-eidh/s, e/s,
sword-shaped, Thphr.HP7.13.1, Str.3.5.
10 ; o)stou=n Gal.2.496 ; xo/ndros the
ensiform cartilage, Id.UP6.3, al.

ci^fo-qh/kh, h(,
scabbard, Hsch., Gloss.

ci^fo-ktone/w,
slay with the sword, Suid.

ci^fo-kto/nos, on,
slaying with the sword, xe/res S.Aj.10 ; di/wgma E.Hel.354 (lyr.).

ci^fo-ma/xaira [ma^], h(,
sabre, Theopomp. Com.25, 7.2, IG12.282.118, 22.1380.

ci^fo-poio/s, o(,
sword-maker, Gloss.

ci/fos [i^], Aeol. ski/fos (q. v.), eos, to/,
sword, c. me/ga, o)cu/, Il.1.194, 4.530, etc., cf. A.Pr.863, Hdt.3.64, X.An.2.2.9, etc. ; c. a)/mfhkes Il.21.118, Od.16.80 ; c. a)rguro/hlon xa/lkeon Il.19.372 ; c. su\n kolew=| . . kai\ e)u+tmh/tw| telamw=ni 7.303 : used by Hom. as equivalent of a)/or and fa/sganon, Od.11.48 (cf. 24, 82), 10.294 (cf. 321) ; cf. ma/xaira.
power of life and death, Lat.
jus gladii, Philostr.VA4.42.
sword-shaped bone in the cuttle-fish (teuqi/s), Arist.HA524b24, PA 654a21, Opp.H.3.558 ; also in the cifi/as, Arist.Fr.325. = cifi/on, Thphr.HP7.13.1.

ci^f-oulki/a, h(,
drawing of a sword, Plu.Arist.18 (pl.), Pomp.69 (pl.).

ci^f-oulko/s, o/n, （e(/lkw）
drawing a sword, xei/r A.Eu.592.

ci^f-ourgo/s, o(,
sword-cutler, Ar.Pax547.
ci^fu/drion, to/, Dim. of ci/fos, only used = telli/nh, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.116, Hsch. ; cf. skifu/drion.

coa^n-hfo/ros, o(,
image-bearer : *coanhfo/roi, title of a play by Sophocles.
coa^/n-ion, to/, Dim. of sq., IG12(3).248.16 (Anaphe, ii B.C.).

co/a^n-on, to/, （ce/w）
image carved of wood, E.Ion1403, X.An.5.3.12 : then, generally,
image, statue, esp. of a god, Acus.28 J., E.IT 1359, Tr.525 (lyr.), 1074 (lyr.), BMus.Inscr.1012 (Chalcedon, i B. C./ i A. D.), Paus.8.17.2, al., Porph.Abst.2.56 ; also of a representation on a scarab, PMag.Leid.V.9.22.
musical instrument, co/an' h(dumelh= S.Fr.238 (anap.).

coa^nopoii/a, h(,
carving of images, Str.16.2.35.
coa^nourgi/a, h(, = foreg., Luc.Syr.D.34.
co-i/+dion, to/, Dim. of sq., PTeb.406.19 (iii A. D.).

co-i/+s, i/+dos, h(,
chisel, IG22.463.40, 11(2).199A87 (Delos, iii B. C.), Supp.Epigr.4.447.40 (Didyma, ii B. C.), etc. ; c. xarakth/ toothed
chisel, IG7.3073.104 (Lebad.) ; c. a)rti/stomos (q.v.), ib.148 ; c. h(mitribh/s Inscr.Délos507 ; poimenikh=s au)tomaqou=s c. APl.4.86.
coo/s, o(, = cusmo/s, o(lko/s, Hsch.

couqo/pteros, on,
with nimble (or perh.
humming) wings, me/lissa（i） E.HF487, Fr.467.4, Lyr.Alex.Adesp.7.13.

couqo/s, h/, o/n,
rapidly moving to and fro, nimble, feu/gete th=s couqh=s deilo/teroi kema/dos Herodic. ap. Ath.5.222a ; ko/mai . . couqoi=sin a)ne/mois e)netru/fwn forou/menai in the
rustling breezes, Chaerem.1.7 ; c. a)lkuo/nes AP9.333 (Mnasalc.) ; c. pte/ruges
rustling, whirring wings of the Dioscuri, h.Hom.33.13 ;
whirring or
steadily-beating wings of the eagle, B.5.17 ; couqa=n e)k pteru/gwn a(du\ kre/kousa me/los, of the cricket, AP7.192 (Mnasalc.).
chirruping or
trilling larynx of the nightingale, e)lqe\ dia\ couqa=n genu/wn e)lelizome/na qrh/nois e)moi=s cunergo/s E.Hel.IIII (lyr.) ; e)lelizome/nh dieroi=s me/lesin ge/nuos couqh=s Ar.Av.214 (anap.) ; di' e)mh=s ge/nuos couqh=s mele/wn *pani\ no/mous i(erou\s a)nafai/nw ib.744 (lyr.) ; of the nightingale itself,
trilling, oi(=a/ tis couqa\ . . *)/itun *)/itun ste/nous' . . a)hdw/n A.Ag.1142 (lyr.) ; w)= fi/lh, w)= couqh/, w)= fi/ltaton o)rne/wn pa/ntwn Ar.Av.676 (lyr.), cf. Theoc.Ep.4.11 ; of song-birds in general, c. ligu/fwna o)/rnea Lyr.Alex.Adesp.7.1 ; c. xelidw/n
twittering swallow, Babr.118.1. of the bee, either
nimble, or
humming (cf. couqo/pteros), S.Fr.398.5, E.IT165 (anap.), 635, Pl.Epigr.32.6, Antiph.52.7, Theoc.7.142, AP9.226.1 (Zon.), v.l. in APl.4.305.3 (Antip.). of the sound produced by a trilling larynx or vibrating wing, couqo\n me/los (of a song-bird)
chirruping note, Opp.H.4.123 ; ou)/resi kai\ skierai=s couqa\ laleu=nta na/pais, of the te/ttic, AP9.373.4. c. i(ppalektruw/n perh.
nimble horse-cock, A.Fr.134, parodied in Ar.Pax 1177, Av.800, Ra.932.
golden yellow, couqw=n te sponda\s melitw=n Emp.128.7 (ap.Porph.Abst.2.21 ; canqw=n ap.Ath.12.510d) ; couqo\s me\n pro/pan ei)=dos, of a species of wolf, Opp.C.3.297 (canqo\s one cod.) ; but couqo\n a)p' a)ne/ros ai(=ma pa/sasqai
red blood, Opp.H.2.452 (v.l. canqo\n u(p').
cou=qros, o(, = strou=qos, Cyran.92.
*cousariastai/, oi(, a guild at Rhodes, IG12(1).963 (dub.).
cu=, v. cei=.
cugg-, for all words so beginning, v. sugg-.
cuzanei, dub. sens. in Supp.Epigr.2.510 (Gortyn, vi B. C.).

cu^h/lh, Dor. cua/lh (Hsch., Suid.), h(, （cu/w）
whittle, curved knife used in shaping a javelin, X.Cyr.6.2.32 ; c. *lakwnikh/, as a weapon, Id.An. 4.7.16, cf. 4.8.25.

cu^la/bion [a^], to/, for cu^lo-la/bion,
fire-tongs, Sch.Opp.H.2.342.
cu^la_lo/h, h(, = a)ga/loxon, Aët.1.131 ; scanned ^_^_ by Heraclit. Gramm. in An.Ox.3.277.

cu^la^m-a/w,
plant or
sow, usu. of green crops or fodder (opp. spei/rw of cereals), mostly c. dat., c. xo/rtw|, xlwroi=s, POxy.499.15 (ii A. D.), PSI4.315.10 (ii A. D.) ; a)ra/kw| POxy.1629.10 (i B. C.) ; but also c. kriqh/n PFlor.85.21 (i A. D.).

cu^la^m-h/, h(,
sowing, planting, xo/rtou, linokala/mhs, ib.41.12 (ii A. D.), POxy.102.11 (iv A. D.).
cu^la^/m-hsis, ews, h(, = foreg., PHamb.27.6 (iii B. C.), PLond.3.1171r.37 (i A. D.).

cu^la^m-hth/s, ou=, o(,
sower, PMich.Zen.32.25 (iii B. C.).

cu^l-a/nhqon [a^], to/, a kind of
dill, Gal.14.732.
cu^l-a/fion, to/, = foreg., Eust.492.37.

cu^l-ei/a, h(,
felling and carrying of wood, Plb.21.39.12, BGU1123.9 (i B. C.), J.BJ6.2.7 ;
supply of wood, Str.5.2.5.
timber, Plb.3.42.3.
wood-work, Id.10.27.10, Callix.I, Hdn.8.4.8.

cu^l-eu/s, e/ws, o(,

cu^l-h/fion, to/, Dim. of cu/lon,
piece of wood, stick, Hp.Steril.230, Alex.98.24, Plb.6.34.9, D.S.4.76 :—misspelt culi/fion D.S.l.c. (v.l.), Thom.Mag.p.253 R. ; culu/fion v.l. in Suid. s.vv. *dioklh=s, o)cu/bafon ; culh/rion EM611.23.

cu^l-i/zomai, Med.,

cu^l-iko/s, h/, o/n, （cu/lon）
of wood, wooden, like wood, Arist.PA674a29 ; karpo\s c., = cu/linos (v. sq.), PSI5.528.46 (iii B. C.), Artem.2.37 ; c. u(/lh
timber, IG12(3).324 (Thera), Gloss. ; c. paraskeuh/ OGI510.7 (Ephesus, ii A. D.) ; culikh/, h(,
timber-monopoly, PTeb.8.26 (iii/ii B. C.) ; culiko/n,

cu^/l-i^nos, h, on,
of wood, wooden, tei=xos Pi.P.3.38 ; do/mos, oi)ki/ai, B.3.49, Hdt.4.108, etc. ; o( c. karpo/s produce
of trees, i. e. fruit, wine, or oil, opp. chro/s (q.v.), Pl.Criti. 115b, cf. OGI55.13 (Telmessus, iii B. C.), Str.15.1.20 : pl., c. karpoi/, opp. sitikoi/, Id.5.4.2, cf. D.S.3.63, Ath.3.78d ; opp. o( *dhmh/trios, IG22.2492.19 ; cu/linai w)=nai, opp. sithrai/, SIG2554.17 (Magn. Mae., ii B. C.) ; toma\ a( culi/na cutting
of timber, IG42(1).76.9 (Epid., ii B. C.). metaph.,
wooden, nou=s AP11.275 (Apollon. Gramm.), cf. 255 (Pall.). cu/linon, to/,
writing-tablet, c. pu/cinon PGrenf. 1.14.12 (ii B. C.).
of cotton, LXX Si.22.16, Plin.HN 19.14.

cu^/l-ion, to/,
block of wood, POxy.901.10 (iv A. D.).
cu^l-ismo/s, o(, = culei/a I, Str.12.2.7, D.H.5.41.
cu^l-isth/s, ou=, o(, = culeu/s, Sch.Pl. Smp.208d.

cu^l-i/ths [i_], ou, o(,
like wood : name of a fish, Hsch. culi=tis (sc. gh=), h(,
timber-bearing land, PPetr.3p.223 (iii B. C.), PCair.Zen.387.9 (iii B. C.), PLille 5.20 (iii B. C.) ; later c. xe/rsos, opp. spo/rimos, PLond.2.267.99 (ii A. D.), BGU703.5 (ii A. D.).
cull-, for words so beginning, v. sull-.
cullei/omai, Boeot. for culeu/omai, dub. in Supp.Epigr.2.185 (cf. p.152) (v B. C.).

cu/llomai, = sula/w,
plunder, SIG56.3 (Argos, v B. C.).

cu^lo-ba/lsa^mon, to/,
balsam-wood, Str.16.2.41, Dsc.1.19, Plin.HN 12.118, Gal.10.466, Gp.7.13.4.

cu^lo/-glu^kon, to/,
siliqua, ib.
cu^lo-glu/fos [glu^], on, gloss on stupoglu/fos, Hsch.

cu^lo-gra^fe/omai, Pass.,

cu^lo-dwni/h (leg. -domi/h）: tektosu/nh, nauph/ghsis, kwphlasi/a, kube/rnhsis, Hsch.

cu^lo-eidh/s, e/s,
like wood, lo/fos to\ xrw=ma c. Clytus I ;
dry, Androm. ap. Gal.14.42 ; cf. culw/dhs.
wooden, quri/des PSI5.547.15, al. (iii B. C.).
cu^lo-ergo/s, o(, = culourgo/s, Supp.Epigr.4.105 (Rome, i A. D.).

cu^lo-qh/kh, h(,
wood-house, Moschioap. Ath.5.208a.
cu^lo-ka/nqhla, ta/, = sq., Gloss.

cu^lo-kanqh/lia, ta/,
wooden pack-saddle, Hsch. s.v. sw/rakon : sg. cu^lo-kanqh/lion, Gloss.

cu^lo-ka/rpa^son, to/,
wood of flax, Gal.19.738.
cu^lo-ka/ru^on [a^], to/, = sq., Aët.16.146.

cu^lo-ka^ru^o/fullon, to/,

cu^lo-ka^si/a, h(, an inferior kind of
cassia, Gal.19.738, Edict.Diocl. 32.53, Aët.16.130.

cu^lo-kataskeu/astos, on,
made of wood, Sch. Lyc.361.

cu^lo-ke/ra_ton, to/,
Ceratonia Siliqua, Alex.Trall.9.3, Steph. in Hp.1.211 D., cf. Gloss.
cu^lo/-kerkos, o(, a gate at Constantinople, AP9.690 tit.

cu^lo-kinna/mwmon [a^], to/,
wood of cinnamon, Dsc.1.14, Plin.HN12.91, Gal.13.185, Gp.8.22.2.
cu^lo/-kokkon, to/, = kera/tion II, Aët.9.32.

cu^lo-ko/lla, h(,
glue for wood, Dsc.3.87, Orib.Syn.2.56.

cu^lo-kope/w,
cut wood, make a clearance, PLille 5.24 (iii B. C.).
beat with a stick, cudgel, of the Roman
fustuarium, Plb. 6.37.1 (Pass.), 6.38.1 : generally, Arr.Epict.3.7.33 :—Pass., ib.4.4.37, POxy.706.13 (ii A. D.).

cu^lo-kopi/a, h(,
wood-cutting, PLille5.49 (iii B. C.), PSI4.323, al. (iii B. C.). = Lat.
fustuarium, Plb.6.37.2.

cu^lo-ko/pos, on, （ko/ptw）
hewing, felling wood, pe/lekus X.Cyr.6.2.36 (v.l. culoto/mos). Subst. -ko/pos, o(,
wood-feller, LXX Jo.9.27(21), Str. 16.4.11.
pecking wood, of the birds keleo/s and knipolo/gos, Arist.HA593a9,14.

cu^lo-kra/mbh, h(,
tree-cabbage, Hippiatr.48 (s.v.l.).
cu^lo-ku/mbh, h(, nickname of an ill-favoured woman, Com.Adesp.1091.

cu^lo-kusti/s, i/dos, h(,
salvia, Gloss. (dub.).

cu^lo-leph/s, e/s,
with woody shell, karpo/s Sch.Nic.Al.108.

cu^lo-logei/a, h(,
gathering of wood, POxy.729.33 (ii A. D.).

cu^lo-luxnou=xos, o(,
wooden lampstand, Alex.344.
cu^lo/-lwtos, o(, = pente/fullon, Dsc.4.42, Gloss.

cu^lo/-maker, to/, indecl.,

cu^lo-metre/w,
measure by cu/la (v. cu/lon v), i. e.
measure the amount of earth excavated, Wilcken Chr.389.27 (ii A. D.).

cu^lo-me/trhs, ou, o(,
official charged with the measuring of earth excavated, PLond.5.1648.8, 13 (iv A. D.).

cu^lo-mi^gh/s, e/s,
mixed with wood, Str.12.7.3.

cu^lo/-moxlon, to/,
wooden bolt, POxy. 1923.21 (v/vi A. D.).
cu^lo-mursi/nh, h(, = mursi/nh a)gri/a, v.l. in Dsc.4.144.

cu/lon [u^], to/ (pl. spelt cu/lea
Abh. Berl. Akad. 1928(6).32 (Cos, v B. C.)),
wood cut and ready for use,
firewood, timber, etc., Hom., mostly in pl., Il.8.507,547, Od.14.418 ; c. nh/i+a ship-
timber, Hes.Op. 808 ; c. nauphgh/sima Th.7.25, X.An.6.4.4, Pl.Lg.706b, D.17.28 ; c. tetra/gwna
logs cut square, Hdt.1.186, cf. Pl.Prt.325d, Arist.EN 1109b7. in pl., also,
the wood-market, e)pi\ cu/la i)e/nai Ar.Fr. 403. in sg.,
piece of wood, log, beam, post, once in Hom., c. au)=on . . h)\ druo\s h)\ peu/khs Il.23.327 ; c. su/kinon
spoon made of fig
wood, Pl.Hp.Ma.291c ;
peg or
lever, Arist.MA701b9 ;
perch, e)pi\ cu/lou kaqeu/dein Ar.Nu.1431 : by poet. periphr., *)argou=s cu/lon A.Fr.20 ; i(/ppoio kako\n c., of the Trojan horse, AP9.152 (Agath.) : hence
anything made of wood, as,
cudgel, club, Hdt.2.63,4.180, Ar.Lys.357, PHal.1.187 (iii B.C.); meta\ cu/lwn ei)sphdh=sai PTeb.304.10 (ii A.D.); cu/lois suntri/yein Luc.Demon.50 ; of the
club of Heracles, Plu.Lyc.30.
an instrument of punishment,
wooden collar, put on the neck of the prisoner, cu/lw| fimou=n to\n au)xe/na Ar.Nu.592 ; e)s tetrhme/non c. e)gkaqarmo/sai . . to\n au)xe/na Id.Lys.680 ; or,
stocks, in which the feet were confined, Hdt.9.37, 6.75, Ar.Eq.367, D.18.129 ; c. e)fe/lkein Polyzel.3 ; e)n tw=| c. dede/sqai Lys.10.16 (v. podoka/kkh), cf. Act.Ap.16.24, OGI483.181 (Pergam., ii A.D.) : also in pl., e)/dhsen e)n toi=s c. And.1.45. pentesu/riggon cu/lon (v. sub voc.) was a combination of both, with holes for the neck, arms, and legs, Ar.Eq.1049.
gallows, krema/sai tina\ e)pi\ cu/lou LXX De.21.22 ; c. di/dumon ib.Jo.8.29 : prov., e)c a)ci/ou tou= cu/lou ka)\n a)pa/gcasqai, i.e. if one must be hanged, at least let it be on a noble tree, App.Prov.2.67, cf. Ar.Ra.736 ; in
NT, of the
cross, Act.Ap.5.30,10.39.
stake on which criminals were impaled, Alex.222.10.
bench, table, esp.
money-changer's table, D.45.33. prw=ton cu/lon front
bench in the Athenian theatre, Ar.Ach.25, V.90, cf. Sch.adlocc. : hence ou(pi\ tw=n cu/lwn the official who had to take care of the
seats, Hermipp.9 (according to Meineke). the Hippocratic
bench, Hp.Fract.13, Art.72. of live wood,
tree, [o)/ros] dasu\ polloi=s kai\ pantodapoi=s kai\ mega/lois cu/lois X.An.6.4.5, cf. Call.Cer.41, Agatharch.55, LXX Ca.2.3, al. : opp. sa/rc, Thphr.HP1.2.6,al. ; tw=| c. tou= de/ndrou a)na/logon th\n legome/nhn ei)=nai gh=n Plot.6.7.11 ; to\ c. th=s a)mpe/lou E.Cyc.572; ei)/ria a)po\ cu/lou, of cotton, Hdt.3.47 ; ei(/mata a)po\ cu/lwn pepoihme/na Id.7.65, cf.Poll.7.75. of persons,
blockhead, APl.4.187 ; of a stubborn person, si/dhro/s tis h)\ c. pro\s ta\s deh/seis Ach.Tat.5.22.
a measure oflength, = 3 (also 2 2/3) cubits, the side of the nau/bion, Hero
*Geom.23.4,11, POxy.669.11,28 (iii A.D.), 1053 (vi/vii A.D.).

cu^lo-na_i/+skion, to/,
wooden shrine, POxy.521 (ii A.D.).

cu^lo/-cesis, ews, h(,
carving, prob. in Supp.Epigr.4.270 (Panamara, i B.C.).

cu^lo-pa^gh/s, e/s,
built on piles, Str.5.1.7.

cu^lo-pa/ktwn, wnos, o(,

cu^lo-pe/dh, h(,
log of wood tied to the feet, Aq.Jb.13.27,33.11.

cu^lo-po/dhs, ou, o(,
with wooden feet, Hdn.Epim.212.

cu^lo-poio/s, o/n,
for carpentry, e)rgasth/rion BGU1053.49 (i B.C.).

cu^lo-pu/lion [pu^], to/,

cu^lo-pu^ri/a, h(, perh.

cu^lo-pw/lhs, ou, o(,
timbermerchant, IG22.1673.17, PLond.3.1177.186 (ii A.D.), Hsch.s.v. surmisth/r.

cu^lo-pwliko/s, h/, o/n,
of a timber-merchant, e)rgasth/rion BGU 1151.40 (i B.C.).

cu^lo-pw/lion, to/,
lignarium, Gloss.

cu^lo-spo/ggion, to/,

cu^lo-stegh/s, e/s,
covered with wood, prob. in POxy.2146.13 (iii A.D.).

cu^lo/-stomos, on,
wooden(i.e.
hard-)
mouthed, of horses, prob. cj. in Hippiatr.115 (-swmoi codd.).

cu^lo-sxi/sths, ou, o(,
one who splits wood, Ptol.Tetr. 179.

cu^lo-tomi/a, h(,
woodcutting, POxy.1631.9 (iii A.D.).

cu^lo-to/mos, o(,
woodcutter, Sammelb.4874 : as Adj., pe/lekus c. v.l. in X.Cyr.6.2.36.

cu^lo-tro/fos, on,
producing timber, o)/rh Str.Chr.4.21.

cu^lo-trw/kths, ou, o(,
eating wood, skw/lhc Suid. s.v. terhdw/n.

cu^lourg-e/w, Ion. cu^lourg-orge/w,
work wood, Hdt.3.113.

cu^lourg-h/s, e/s,
made of wood, dia/fragma Lyd.Mag.3.37.

cu^lourg-i/a, h(,
working of wood, carpentry, A.Pr.451, IG12.347.35.

cu^lourg-iko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for carpentry, E.Fr.988 : h( -kh/ (sc. te/xnh), = culourgi/a, Pl.Phlb.56b.

cu^lourg-o/s, o(,
carpenter, joiner, IG12.373.235, Poll.7.101 ; cf. culoergo/s.

cu^lo-fa/gos [a^], on,
eating wood, skw/lhc Str.12.7.3 ; cj. for u(lo-in Ant.Lib.22.5.

cu^lo-fa^nh/s, e/s,
showing wood : to\ c. tou= kataskeua/smatos the
exposed wooden structure, D.S.20.96.
resembling wood, Archig. ap. Orib.8.2.2.

cu^lo-fqo/ron, to/, an insect
that destroys wood, Arist.HA557b13 codd. (fort. -fo/ron
that carries wood).

cu^lo-fore/w,
carry wood, of a slave or mule, Men.Her. 52, PSI6.667.2 (iii B.C.), Str.14.2.24.
carry a stick, as the Cynics did, Luc.Pisc.24.
produce timber, Str.Chr.2.2.

cu^lo-fori/a, h(,
wood-carrying, Lys.Fr.325 S.
wood-offering, LXXNe.10.34(35).

cu^lo-fo/rios, on,
belonging to a wood-offering, h( tw=n culofori/wn e(orth/ the Jewish
feast of Tabernacles, J.BJ 2.17.6.

cu^lo-fo/ros, on,
carrying wood, qera/pontes c. Dosiad.Hist.1 : as Subst.,
wood-porter, Epicur.Fr.172, Aq.De.29.11(10). Subst.,
wood-offerer, LXXNe.13.31.

cu^lo/-fraktos, on,
fenced with wood, c. ge/fura, =
pons sublicius, D.H.3.55,5.24,9.68.

cu^lo-xa/rtia, ta/,

cu^lox-i/zomai, Dor. cu^lox-i/sdomai, = culi/zomai, e)rei/kas Theoc.5.65.

cu^/lox-os, h(,
thicket, copse, cu/loxon ka/ta boskomena/wn Il.5.162 ; baqei/hs e)k culo/xoio 11.415, 21.573 ; e)n culo/xw| . . le/ontos in his
lair, Od.4.335, cf. 19.445 ; kranah=| kei/meq' e)ni\ c. AP7.445 (Pers.) : also in late Prose, Palaeph.14 : pl., Stud.Pont.3.16 (Amisus, ii/i B.C.), Coluth.42, Anacreont. 29.5.

cu^l-o/w,
turn into wood :—Pass.,
become wood, Thphr.HP1.2.7 : metaph., of persons suffering from tetanus, oi(onei\ c. Herod.Med.in Rh.Mus.58.90.
make of wood, gau=lon IG11(2).203 A53 (Delos, iii B.C.), cf. 12(3).1270.15 (Syme, ii/i B.C.), LXX 2 Ch.3.5 :—Pass., ib. Ez.41.16 ; nao\s e)culwme/nos SIG996.18 (Smyrna, i A.D.).

cu^l-w/dhs, es,
woody, hard as wood, Hp.Vict.2.65, Arist.Mete.387a32, Thphr.HP 6.2.2 (Sup.),7.9.3, Plu.2.953d ;
of the nature of wood, Corn.ND 19.
of the colour of wood, brown, Thphr.HP7.3.2.

cu^/l-wma, atos, to/,
piece of woodwork, IG11(2).163A20,29 (Delos, iii B.C.), 12 (2).14.9 (Mytil. ; cu/loma lapis).
cu^l-wma/tion, to/, Dim. of foreg., ib.11(2).199B51 (Delos, iii B.C.).

cu^l-w/n, w=nos, o(,
place for wood,
wood-house, ib.159 A56, al. (ib.,iii B.C.), Inscr.Délos399 A85 (ii B.C.), Gloss.

cu^l-wni/a, h(,

cu^l-w/rofon, to/,
wooden roof, ib.12(3).1102 (Melos).

cu^/l-wsis, ews, h(,
wood-work of a building, h( c. tw=n oi)kiw=n Th.2.14 ; stoih=s Milet.3.32 (iii B.C.), J.AJ3.6.5.
cumm-, for words so beginning, v. suum-.
cu/n, v. su/n : for compds. of cun-, v. sun-.
cuna/n, cuna/wn, v. cunh/wn.

cu^neei/kosi, Ep. for sunei/kosi,
twenty together, Od.14.98.
cune/wn, v. cunh/wn.
cu/nhbos: sumpo/ths, Phot. : cunh/bios (sic): sumpo/ths, sunh=lic, Hsch.

cu_nh/i+os, h, on, Ep. and Ion. (cu/neios is not found),
common : neut. pl. cunh/i+a, ta/,
common stock, Il.1.124, 23.809.

cu/nhma, atos, to/,
javelin-throwing on horseback while on the wheel, Celtic word, Arr.Tact.42.4.
cu_nh/wn, onos, o(, Dor. cuna/wn [a_],

cuna/n; Ion.cune/wn ; Att. cunw/n:—
joint-owner, partner, c. gen., kakw=n e)/rgwn Hes.Th.595 ; e)/rgwn a)rgale/wn ib.601 ; e(lke/wn cuna/ones, i.e.
afflicted by sores, Pi.P.3.48 : abs., cuna/n
friend, Id.N.5.27 ; cunw/n S.Fr.1074 ; parqe/nou se/bas h)/meiya, pai/dwn d' e)zu/ghn cuna/oni prob. in A.Fr.99.6 ; dusi\n zeuxqei=sa fi/lois cuna/osi te/knwn, i.e. having married two husbands, Epigr.Gr.241a3 (Smyrna). as Adj., a(/la cune/wna the salt
on the common table, Alex.Aet.3.15.
cu/nie, cuni/ei, cu/nion, v. suni/hmi.

c<*>nodoth/r, h=ros, o(,
bounteous giver, epith. of Apollo, AP9.525.15.

cu_no/s, h/, o/n, = koino/s,
common, public, general, c. kako/n Il.16.262 ; gai=a d' e)/ti c. pa/ntwn 15.193 ; c. *)enua/lios, i.e. war
hath an even hand, 18.309 ; c. a)nqrw/pois *)/arhs Archil.62 ; also of Apollo and Dionysus, AP9.524.15,525.15 ; cunai\ ga\r to/te dai=tes e)/san cunoi\ de\ qo/wkoi Hes.Fr. 82 ; c. d' e)sqlo\n tou=to po/lhi/+ te panti/ te dh/mw| Tyrt.12.15 ; c. *(ellh/nwn te kai\ barba/rwn lo/gos Hdt.4.12 ; c. pa=si a)gaqo/n Id.7.53 ; c. do/ru S. Aj.180 (lyr.) ; to\ c.
state, government (cf. koino/s), SIG37 A 3 (Teos, v B.C.) ; cuna\ d' e)lpi/zw le/gein
for the common good, A.Th.76 ; e)n cunw=|
in common, Pi.P.9.93 : dat. cunh=| as Adv., = koinh=|, A.Supp.367, A.R. 2.802, Call.Dian.36 : also neut. pl., cu/n' a)le/gein Pi.I.8(7).51 ; xa/ris cu/n' a)po/keitai cj. in S.OC1752 (anap.) : regul. Adv. cunw=s Epigr.Gr. 520.6.—Ep. (koino/s first in Hes.), Ion. (Heraclit.113, Hdt., v. supr.), and Lyr. ; twice in A. (trim.), twice in S.(lyr.) ; not in E. or Att. Prose.

cu_no/-frwn, onos, o(, h(,
friendly-minded, of Apollo, AP9.525.15.

cu_no-xa^rh/s, e/s,
rejoicing with all alike, of Apollo, ibid.

cu_n-o/w,
cause to participate, tina\ a)ni/h| Nonn.D.17.220:—Med., = koinou=sqai, Nearch. ap. Arr.Ind.20.4, Man.2.493.
cu_n-w/n, v. cunh/wn.

cu_n-wni/a, h(, = koinwni/a,
partnership, fellowship, a)lw/phc kai)eto\s cunwni/hn e)/meican Archil.86.
cu_n-wno/s, o(, = koinwno/s, Theognost. Can.68.
cu^nwri/s, i/dos, h(, v. sunwri/s.

cu^ra/fion, to/, Dim. of curo/n, Sch.Ar.Ach.849 ;
surgical knife, Gal. 14.786.

cu^r-e/w, Trag. and Att. (v. infr.) ; cu^ra/w, Plu.2.180b, Artem.1.22 (also in pres. Med., D.S.1.84, Palaeph.32, and pres. Pass., Luc.Cyn. 14) ; both forms in codd. of Hdt. ; cf. cu/rw : fut. -h/sw LXX De.21.12 : aor. e)cu/rhsa Hp.Aff.4, Hdt.5.35, etc. :—Med., fut. curh/somai LXX Ez.44.20, J.BJ2.15.1, Hsch. s.v. priamwqh/somai : aor. e)curhsa/mhn LXX Nu.6.19, al., Luc.DMeretr.12.5 :—Pass., fut. -hqh/somai LXXLe. 13.33 : pf. e)cu/rhmai (v. infr.) : (curo/n):—
shave, curou=ntes (v.l. -w=ntes) tw=n paidi/wn th\n kefalh/n Hdt.2.65 : c. dupl. acc., curh/sas min ta\s tri/xas Id.5.35 : prov. of danger or pain, curei= ga\r e)n xrw=|
it shaves close, 'touches the quick', S.Aj.786 ; curei=n e)pixeirei=n le/onta, of a dangerous undertaking, 'beard the lion', Pl.R.341c :—Med. and Pass.,
shave oneself or
have oneself shaved, cureu=ntai (v.l. -w=ntai) Hdt.2.36 ; e)curhme/nos ibid., Ar.Th.191 ; curou/menon Alex.264 : also c. acc., cureu=ntai (v.l. -w=ntai) pa=n to\ sw=ma they
shave their whole body or
have it
shaved, Hdt.2.37 ; ta\s o)fru/as, th\n kefalh/n, ib.66 ; e)curhme/nos th\n kefalh/n
with one's head
shaved, Luc.Merc.Cond.1.

cu^r-h/khs, es, (a)kh/ A)
keen as a razor, X.Cyn.10.3. Pass.,
close-shaven, ka/ra E.Ph.[372], El.335 ; koura=| curh/kei with
close tonsure, Id.Alc.427. = sq., Ael.Dion.Fr.265, cf. Phot., Suid.

cu^r-h/simos, on,
fit for shaving, Ael.Dion.Fr.265.
cu^r-hsmo/s, o(, = foreg., Hdn.Epim. 180.

cu^r-hth/s, ou=, o(,
barber, BGU630v10(ii/iii A.D.).

cu^r-i/as, ou, o(,
shaveling, Poll.4.133, Hsch. s.v. priamwqh/somai.
cu^r-i/zw, = cure/w, Sch.Nic.Al.410 :—Med., fut. inf. -iei=sqai, f.l. for curei=sqai, Alciphr.3.66.
cu^/r-ion, to/, Dim. of curo/n, Daimach.4 J.(pl.).

cu^ri/s, i/dos, h(,
gladwyn, Iris foetidissima, Dsc.4.22, Plin.HN21.143, Gal.12.87 :—also written ci/ris, Thphr.HP9.8.7, Choerob. in An.Ox. 2.242 ; ceiri/s, Hsch. ; cei/rhs, Ar.Fr.831 ; cf. ciri/s. pl., a kind of
shoe, Phot.

cu/risma [u^], atos, to/,
shaving, bostru/xwn Tz.H.2.537.
curmeu/esqai : a)diakri/tws lalei=n kai\ kauxa=sqai (Att.), Hsch.

cu^ro-do/kh, h(,
razor-case, Ar.Th.220 : written curodo/xh in Poll.10.140.
cu^ro-qh/kh, h(, v.l. for foreg., Id.2.32.

cu^ro/n, to/,
razor, E.El.241, Ar.Ec.65, Th.219, Nic.Al.411, Plu. Art.29, etc.: prov., e)pi\ curou= i(/statai a)kmh=s . . , o)/leqros h)e\ biw=nai death or life is balanced on a
razor's edge, Il.10.173 : freq. in later authors, to express a delicately balanced like lihood of failure or success, a)kma=s e(stakui=an e)pi\ curou= *(ella/da Simon.97 ; e)pi\ c. ga\r a)kmh=s e)/xetai h(mi=n ta\ prh/gmata Hdt.6.11 ; ki/ndunos e)pi\ c. i(/statai a)kmh=s Thgn.557 ;
bebw\s . . e)pi\ c. tu/xhs S.Ant.996 ; e)/bht' e)pi\ c. ; E.HF630 ; e)pi\ c. ei)=nai Theoc.22.6 ; e)pi\ c. e(sthke/nai Luc.JTr.3.

cu^ropoio/s, o(,
razor-maker, Gloss.
cu^ro/s, o(, = curo/n, Archipp.45, Alciphr.3.66, v.l. in AP11.288 (Pall.) ; c. ei)s a)ko/nhn, prov. of lucky meetings, Suid.

cu^rourgo/s, o/n,
tonsorial : c. a)nqrwpa/rion Zos.Alch.p.116B.

cu^rofore/w,
carry a razor, Ar.Th.218.
curr-, for words so beginning, v. surr- ; cf. cu/n.

cu/rw [u_], collat. form for cure/w : impf. e)/cu_ron Luc.Pseudol.27 : aor. part. cu/ras Hp.Morb.3.1, Tz.H.9.231 :—Med.,
have oneself shaved, cu/resqai to\n pw/gwna Chrysipp.Stoic.3.198 ; ta\s kefala/s Plu.2.352c (dub.l.) : aor. I, th\n k. cura/menos ib.336e, cf. Luc.Syr.D.53,55, Alciphr. 3.43.

cu/si^los [u_], on,
shaven, smooth, Sophr.55.

cu=s-is, ews, h(, (cu/w)
ulceration, erosion, tou= e)nte/rou Hp.Acut.60.
excoriation, Aret.CD1.3.
scraping, filing, Hp.VC14, cf. Gal. 14.781, Ammon.in Int.23.21, PMed.inArch.Pap.4.270 ;
polishing, EM611.20. (cu/sis is f.l. in codd.).

cu/s-ma, atos, to/,
filings, shavings, Hp.Aph.7.68, Inscr.Délos442 B96 (ii B. C.): in pl., cu/smata cu/lwn Apollod.Poliorc.145.13 ; c. e)le/fantos Orib.14.62.1.
lint, Erot. s.v. a)/xnh o)qoni/ou. in pl.,
shreds of flesh, Hp.Acut.59 ; e)nte/rwn Gal.8.382, 18(1).730, cf. Dsc.4.176. in pl.,
particles, motes in the sunbeam, yuxh\n ei)=nai ta\ e)n tw=| a)e/ri c. Arist.de An.404a3, cf. Pr.913a9.
that which is scratched on a thing : hence cu/smata = gra/mmata, Hsch.

cus-ma/lion, to/,
erosive plaster, Cyran. 40.

cus-ma/tion, to/, Dim. of cu=sma I. Ic, Hp.Epid.7.84. c. o)qo/nhs
strip of linen, Aët.8.27.

cus-ma^tw/dhs, es,
full of cu/smata I. Ic, diaxwrh/mata Hp.Prog.11, cf. Acut.52 (Comp.), Coac.621, Aret. SD2.9.

cus-mh/, h(, in pl.,
scratchings, i.e. critical marks in a Ms., AP9.206 (Eupith.); gra/mmata le/getai dia\ to\ grammai=s kai\ cusmai=s tupou=sqai D.T.630.28 (v.l. -oi=s ap.Sch.).
scab, as a term of abuse, Sophr.53.

cus-mo/s, o(,
itching, irritation, cusmoi\ tou= sw/matos o(/lou Hp.Aph.3.31 ; c. e)n tw=| pleu/moni Id.Loc.Hom.14.
cuss-, for words so beginning, v. suss- ; cf. cu/n.
custa/llion, to/, Dim. of cu=stron II,IG11(2).203B76(Delos, iii B.C.).

custarx-e/w,
hold the office of custa/rxhs, Rev.Arch.1916(1).338 (Sinope), PLond.3.1178.58 (ii A. D.).

custa/rx-hs, ou, o(, (custo/s)
president of an athletic association, o(\n basilh=s . . sth=san a)eqloqe/thn custa/rxhn IG 3.1171, cf. POxy.1050.7 (ii/iii A. D.), Sammelb.5725, etc. ; dia\ bi/ou c. IGRom.4.1215 (Smyrna), IG14.1102, al.

custarx-i/a, h(,
office of custa/rxhs, tuxo/nta th=s dia\ ge/nous c. SIG1073.9 (Olympia, ii A. D.): in pl., IGRom.4.1419b1, Delph.3(1).466.6.
cust-hri/dion, to/, Dim. of foreg., Phryn.PSp.88B.

cust-h/rios, on,
of or
for scraping: to\ c., dentist's
instrument for scaling teeth, Paul.Aeg.6.28.

custi^dwto/s (sc. xitw/n), o(, (custi/s II)
garment with ornament in strigil form (<*>), IG22.1514.11.

custiko/s, h/, o/n,
of or
for scraping : h( -kh/
the art of polishing, Sch. D.T.p.110H.
corrosive, xumo/s Phylotim. ap. Ath.3.81b, Gal. Nat.Fac.2.9 ; custiko\n e)/xei tw=n e)nte/rwn Alex.Trall.Febr.I ; of plasters, Orib.Fr.88. (custo/s)
taking exercise in a xystus: hence,
athlete, xysticorum certationes Suet.Aug.45 ; a)nh\r c. Gal.13.1023 ; c. a)qlhtai/ BCH28.22 ; c. su/nodos Athletic Association, h( i(era\ qumelikh\ kai\ c. s. OGI713.3 (Alexandria, iii A. D.) ; h( i(era\ c. peripolistikh\ oi)koumenikh\ su/nodos IG14.956B19, cf. PLond.3.1178.2 (ii A. D.), etc.

custi/s, i/dos, h(,
robe of rich and soft material reaching to the feet, worn by women of quality, Ar.Lys.1190 (lyr.), Antiph.99, Eub.90.3, Theoc.2.74 ; tru/fhma parufe/s, custi/da Ar.Fr.320 ; tai=s c. tai=s xrusopa/stois Eub.135 ; c. malaka/s Plu.2.406d ; worn by great men (esp. by victorious charioteers in their chariots) as a robe of state, Ar.Nu.70, cf. Pl.R.420e ; by Trag. heroes, Cratin.268, Duris 14, 70 J., cf. Harp. s.v., AB284 :—Hsch. and Tim.Lex., who say it was also used by Com., prob. refer to the use of the women's c. on the Com. stage. = cu/stra, stleggi/s, Epich.97, Diph.52. (Perh. from custo/s, h/, o/n, as epith. of cloth, orig.
garment made of cut (shorn, clipped) fabric, such as fustian, plush, velvet, etc. ; cf. cu/w IV, custo/s 3 : for the semantic relation between custi/s and custo/n (pole, spear, etc.), and cu/w, cf. ONorse
skrúd 'some kind of textile fabric',
skrúd-kloedi 'suit of fine stuff', Engl.
shroud 'loppings of a tree, branch, bough', both cogn. with
shred.）

custobo/los, on,
spear-darting, of Dionysus, AP9.524.15.

cus-to/n, to/, (cu/w, lit.
shaved, sc. do/ru)
shaft, pole, e.g. spear-
shaft, c. xalkh=res Il.11.260 ; makroi=si c. 13.497, cf. 15.677 ; opp. lo/gxai (the head), Hdt.1.52, cf. Plu.Rom.20.
spear, E.Hec.920 (lyr.) ; a horseman's
lance, X.Cyr.4.5.58, cf. 7.1.33, Plu.Aem.16 : pl. custoi/ Jul.Or.2.60a codd. v. custo/s.

cus-to/s, h/, o/n, (cu/w)
shaved, whittled with a knife or plane, a)ko/ntia Hdt.2.71 (nisi del. a)ko/ntia) ; ka/mac Ar.Fr.404 ; be/los Antiph.112 ; do/rata Arr.Tact.40.4.
scraped, shredded, grated, turo/s Antiph.113.18 ; moto/s pledget
of lint, Gal.14.795 ; i)o\s o( c.
collected by scraping, Dsc.5.79 ; me/tron c. with the top
raked off, not heaped up, PFay.84.7 (ii A. D.).
trimmed, cropped with scissors, maxai/ra| cu/st' e)/xwn trixw/mata Ephipp.14.6.

cus-to/s, o( (in full custo\s dro/mos Aristias 5), also custo/n, to/, BCH23.566 (Delph., iii B. C.), Inscr.Délos409A13 (ii B. C.):—
walking-place in the grounds of a private residence, X.Oec.11.15 ; in a gymnasium, Plu.2.133d, OGI764.42 (Pergam.) ; name of a gymnasium at Elis containing trees and racing-tracks, Paus.6.23.1 ; open-air
walks among trees and statuary, Vitr.5.11.5 ; ta\ tw=n c. a)/lsh Philostr.VA8.26.
covered colonnade in a gymnasium, for winter exercise, Vitr. l.c., Inscr.Délos l.c.
meeting of athletes from various places to compete in sports, a)rxiereu\s tou= su/mpantos c. IG14.1102, al., cf.5(1).669 (Sparta) ; opp. custikh\ su/nodos, Inscr.Olymp.436. (Expld. by Paus. l.c. as a
clearing, from the action of Heracles in
clearing out (a)nacu/ein) the thorn-bushes from the c. at Elis ; perh. orig. 'raked (ground)'.)

custo-fore/w,
carry a lance, in Pass. (cf. dorufore/w), Alc.Oxy.1789 Fr.<*>i8.

custo-fo/ros, on,
lance-bearing, of horsemen, X.Cyr.7.5.41, 8.3.16, Plb.5.53.2, D.S.19.27, Ascl.Tact.2.12, Arr.Tact.4.4, Plu. Flam.17.

cu/s-tra, h(,
scraper used after bathing, Hp.Nat.Mul.42, Diph.52, PCair.Zen.488.1 (iii B. C.), OGI339.77 (Sestos, ii B. C.), PLond.3.402 ii 25 (ii B. C.), Agathin. ap. Orib.10.7.2 : later word for stleggi/s, acc. to Luc.Lex.5, Hellad. ap. Phot.Bibl.p.533 B., Poll.3.154, Phryn. 266. = w)tegxu/ths, Archig. ap. Gal.12.620.

cus-trei/a, h(,
set of graving-tools, PFay.347 (ii A. D.).

cus-tri/on, to/, Dim. of cu/stra, PLond.2.191.8 (ii A. D.).
small raspatory at the end of a forceps, Paul.Aeg.6.25.
cus-tri/s, i/dos, h(, = cu/stra, Hsch.s.v. stelgi/s.

custro-eidh/s, e/s,
shaped like a cu/stra, Erot.s.v. a)/mbhn ; gwni/a Procl.in Euc.pp.127,238 F.

custro-lh/ku^qos, o(,
slave who carried his master's custri/s
and lh/kuqos
to and from the bath, Hsch.

cu=stron, to/,
scythe fixed to chariots, D.S.17.53. = custh/r, BSA27.228 (Sparta, ii A.D.) : condemned by Thom.Mag.p.252 R.

custro-poio/s, o/n,
making cu=strai, Gloss. ; perh. to be read in Dexipp.in Cat.12.7.

custro-fu/lac [fu^], a^kos, o(,
place or
box for keeping cu=strai
in, Artem.1.64.

custr-o/w,
channel, flute, in Pass., [ki/ones] e)custrwme/noi Ath.Mitt. 14.109 (Mylasa).

custr-wto/s, o/n,
fluted, of pillars, Aq., Thd.3 Ki.6.18, PLond.3.755B3 (iv A. D.) ;
chamfered, purami/s Hero
*Stereom.2.66.1.
cu/fos, to/, (cu/w) coined as etym. of ci/fos, EM611.8.

cu/w, Ep. impf. cu=on Od.22.456 : aor. e)/cu_sa Il.14.179, Hp.VC14 (e)g-cu/sh| [u^] is prob. f.l. for -ce/sh| in E.Fr.298 codd. Stob., and so die/cu^sen for -e/cesen in Nonn.D.39.321) :—Med., aor. e)cu_sa/mhn X.Cyr. 6.2.32 :—Pass., Sophr.150 : aor. e)cu/sqhn Arist.HA570a9, Thphr. CP5.6.13 : pf. e)/cusmai Gal. 13.544, (peri-) Hp.Mul.2.192 :—
scratch, scrape, li/stroisin da/pedon cu=on they
scraped the floor with rakes, Od. l.c. ;
scratch, prov. to\n cu/onta a)nticu/ein 'claw me, claw thee', Sophr.149 ; ge/ronta kwnei/w| cu/onta th\n gh=n
scratching a diagram
on the earth, Call.Iamb.1.122 ; tw=| daktu/lw| [th\n gh=n] Sch.Ar.Ach.31 ; gra/yai to\ cu=sai para\ toi=s palaioi=s (i. e. in Hom., cf. gra/fw I. 1) D.T. 630.28 : metaph., cu=sai a)po\ gh=ras o)loio/n
scrape off, get rid of, sad old age, h.Ven.224 ; pa=san h)|o/na cu/wn
scouring the whole coast, of a fisherman, Babr.6.1 ; = e)picu/w,
graze, of stars which touch the horizon but do not set, Euc.Phaen.Prooem.p.2H. :—Med.,
scratch oneself, cuo/menoi h(/dontai Democr.127 ; cuo/menoi pro\s ta\ de/ndra e)kqli/bousi tou\s o)/rxeis Arist.HA578b4, cf.Pr.953b37 ; th\n kefalh\n cu/stra| c. Luc. Lex.5 :—Pass., tou= phlou= cusqe/ntos
being scraped up, Arist.HA570a9 ; of land,
to beeroded, scoured away, by water, cusqei/shs kai\ a)fanisqei/shs gh=s POxy.1911.193 (vi A. D.).
shred, cu/wn th\n sa/rka [tou= xaradriou=] e)n oi)/nw| dido/nai pi/nein prob. in Hp.Int.37 ; [tiqu/mallon] e)n oi)/nw| cu/onta pi/nein Thphr.HP9.11.2.
shape by whittling, shaving, or
planing, kw/pas ib.5.1.7 :—Med., palto\n cu/sasqai
whittle oneself a javelin, X.l.c.
shear the nap of cloth, e(ano\n e(/saq', o(/n oi( *)aqh/nh e)/cus' a)skh/sasa Il.14.179 ; cf. custo/s 3, custi/s 1.
